column7: Comment Text

Dear FCC, net neutrality is vital to the continued prosperity of the internet and our nation. ISP's cannot be trusted to self-regulate, as shown by multiple instances of throttling, arbitrary data caps, and other anti-consumer behavior. I must implore you NOT to roll back the protections afforded by the FCC during the previous administration, as that will lead directly to an aggressive dismantling of Net Neutrality as a living concept. ISPs must be faced with "utilities-style" regulation as they have shown they cannot be trusted otherwise. Thank you for listening to citizens, who I believe will be overwhelmingly against the elimination of these common-sense regulations.

Net neutrality is extremely important to the people of America since it ensures we all are equal when going online. To struck it down would be cruel and a blatant power grab to give the rich an even bigger advantage over the rest of us.

Dear FCC,  I am writing you today because I'm hoping that my voice actually counts. I am self employed and need a free and open internet in order to survive. Killing Net Neutrality would end all that and put my well being in danger. Millions of citizens across the US need an open internet in order to function properly. The removal of Net Neutrality would not only ruin this ability but severely place our country behind the rest of the world. Our leadership in terms of guiding the internet would be put into question. So please. For me, for my fellow Americans, and for the country itself, keep Net Neutrality in place and DO NOT push forward this harmful Restoring Internet Freedom. Thank you.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

My review of your proposed actions & reasoning leaves me skeptical this department's grasp of the situation. Your recounting of history seems to completely ignore the .com bubble (and burst thereof), its impact on events leading into the Great Recession, the lack of infrastructure development & competition across the country outside of certain urban hubs that lead directly to the failure of true U.S. competitiveness in the world market, its direct injury and contribution to the continued lack of economic recovery across same parts of the U.S. in the aftermath of the Great Recession, and the simple fact that infrastructure and ISP companies have folded and merged until there's really only 3-4 big near-monopolies left, for the most part. And they have effectively throttled development on their own already, and that's before one takes into account their (essentially) non-compete agreements between each other, leaving many markets in the country with one or two choices to 'vote with their dollars' between.

While I can appreciate being wary of over-regulation, the very rules and actions you are decrying and attempting to move against were made in response to real world events and situations. Your proposals are, at best, mired in fantasies of a market that doesn't exist. *If* you were willing to forcibly break up Time Warner, Comcast, and the others, your policies MIGHT work. Maybe. But nothing I see here, nor any other words or actions on the government's part, indicates any motivation in that direction.

Your ideals of light regulation are nice, in their fashion. But under that regulatory dream, the U.S. has effectively floundered and failed, staying locally and internationally competitive only by virtue of out-market surpluses (such as education) and sheer, stubborn American spirit. And instead of rewarding that spirit, your proposed rules serve to strangle it.

You are our oversight representatives, ultimately answerable to flesh-and-blood citizens, not corporations. There are other ruleset models that address market problems much better than what you've proposed, without betraying the citizenry into the richest companies' hands. Stop bullshitting both me and yourselves, and go back to the drawing board.

Hi, my name is Max from Smithfield, UT. I'd like to register my opinion in support of Net Neutrality. Chairman Pai's recent decision to move toward a non-Net-Neutrality position of the FCC is a poor decision for the American people and will result in higher rates, lower competition, and a severe lack of innovation due to content providers having all the power.

This is far from a Republican or Democrat issue. In fact, maintaining Net Neutrality will result in fewer regulations as maintaining this single position staves off the inevitable need for future regulation once ISPs begin to abuse their power and gouge customers for every penny they can due to the lack of competition in the retail broadband market.

Thank you for registering my opinion on the matter. I hope that the FCC will act in accordance with the will of the American People in regards to this matter.

Thank you, Max

Net neutrality is a required service to prevent abuse and manipulation of the internet.  Without it, service providers can and will prioritize or lock access to sites of their choosing if they compete or are in conflict with them, destroying competition.  services which rely on the internet to conduct business will have to pay more to maintain their transactions, driving up costs for consumers, on top of permitting service providers to inflate their prices while reducing their services.  No-one wins by taking away net neutrality, as it was already shown in the short time it was unlawfully undone in the time before it was restored in 2015 that Comcast, verizon and the other providers were taking advantage of that power.  To remove net neutrality is to destroy the internet, which has become an essential service in our modern era.

Hi, my name is Bailey Davis from Saint Paul, Minnesota . I'd like to register my opinion in support of Net Neutrality. Chairman Pai's recent decision to move toward a non-Net-Neutrality position of the FCC is a poor decision for the American people and will result in higher rates, lower competition, and a severe lack of innovation due to content providers having all the power.

Please keep net neutrality.  This isn't just consumer protection, but protection for the emergent primary system of communication, entertainments, education, commerce, and civic participation.  A lot is at stake here, and keeping neutrality in place is the best way to move forward.

Net neutrality has been the cornerstone principle of the Internet since its inception.  Because of this, we have experienced an age of unrivaled sharing of ideas, growth and competition.  We will not let you destroy that by allowing private companies to strangle innovation.  I don't believe this is intended to fix a problem, other than the handful of ISP monopolies in the country are not making large enough profit margins.

Please keep the net neutrality rules in place. As a young programmer who has worked to drive innovation in the automation sector since I was a teenager, I can imagine nothing more damaging than removing net neutrality. Net neutrality is what allows for innovation, growth, and freedom. Removing net neutrality will only make it more difficult for younger brands and products to supplant older ones. By removing these protections, we will limit future growth and innovation and begin a cycle of stagnation.

Killing net neutrality is a terrible idea. Quite frankly, I am astounded and amazed that anyone(or committee) could be so incredibly and mind boggling stupid makes me question the very principles of evolution, as it would seem preposterous that such belligerence could be bred into the human race over such a short period of time. Net neutrality is necessary, and I would go so far as to say that it is one of the cornerstones of a modern democracy, free speech, and the american dream. Net neutrality is a key component of a functional and informed democracy for several reasons: 1) net neutrality allows for the internet to be a relatively unbiased source of information, as it is possible to look at different sources of news to inform one's self. \nThe next point is that net neutrality is necessary to protect freedom of information, and freedom of speech. Without net neutrality laws, it is possible and even conceivable that ISP's would restrict access to certain domains, news sources, and web sites. This would be in direct violation of the freedom of information laws, as even the act of making it more difficult to access certain information, while mayhaps not breaking the law itself, would destroy and hide the purpose of the law. \nNow, certain members of the house and senate, or of this committee, may say that the internet is not the only method of spreading or accessing information, however in the 21st century, the internet and all the information that can be found on it, is quite frankly necessary. Furthermore, the american dream will be destroyed when you destroy net neutrality. without the ability to equal opportunity on the web, startups, small businesses and other small but necessary parts of a functioning economy will be put at a disadvantage.

This new proposal will take away my freedoms - not grant me any. Net neutrality is a critical cornerstone of a free and open internet. There is essentially no competition at my home and many others. I have exactly one choice of internet service provider, which gives that one provider a stranglehold on a service critical to me. Government regulation is the only thing keeping that one provider from taking egregious advantage of me.

The current Net Neutrality rules, including the Title II classification are necessary to keep ISPs honest. They have shown, repeatedly, that they will push the rules as much as possible. Fewer rules will not change that. In addition, ISPs are doing just fine under these rules. Stocks are doing well, profits are doing well, and infrastructure investment is continuing. There is no reason to repeal the Open Internet order, nor to repeal Title II classification. Vote for consumers, but businesses. That's what the FCC exists for.

This course of action would be contrary to the spirit of the internet itself - to unite all people on equal terms regardless of nation, religion, or of course ISP. Thanks for reading my comment!

Paragraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Thanks for reading my comment.

At what point are legislators going to finally give up and admit that private corporations in our capitalist system will always take whatever means are available to maximize profit.  "Trusting" businesses like Standard Oil and Lehman Brothers has led to nationwide, or even worldwide, financial crisis more than once.  \nFurthermore, the internet is undeniably a utility. A student can not receive a modern education without it. Housebound citizens can not maintain independence. Families of those who serve our country can not see their loved one smile back at them from over seas. A mother shopping for groceries can't check her bank account. The list goes on and on. Internet is a need in our society. Thereby it qualifies as a public service, and as such, must not be controlled by private interests.

Please stand up and reject any attempts to wreck net neutrality. Thank you.\n\nThe proposal to remove title II provisions for ISPs will hurt consumers, stifle businesses and harm americans' standing in the world. ISPs have violated the terms of their contracts to line their pockets at the expense of consumers and forces startups to fail, because the barriers to entry are too high.

Our EX-LIAR-in-CHIEF only wanted to put this tax on the internet is so he can control who uses it and restrict those that do use it.

My Internet provider is essentially a monopoly.  It is the cable company.  Since the phone company is not investing the capital to upgrade the POTS copper to reach speeds faster than 3MBit in our area, we have only one choice for a higher speed connection.  I pay a premium for that connection.  I expect the cable company to connect me with who I want, when I want, and at the speed I've paid for.  I don't want it able to throttle my communications based on who owns what on the other end, or what protocol I'm using, or what service I'm connecting to.  The current payment model which has me pay for my connection bandwidth (through to their connection to the backbone) should assure that I get the speed I pay for without them asking folks on the other end to enhance their revenues.

That current payment model has had a significant benefit.  It has allowed entrepreneurs a fair shake when starting new businesses (beneficial to our country).  t should be kept in place to continue that trend.

As best I can tell, the proposal benefits only a few companies.  It is detrimental to both consumers and new businesses / entrepreneurs.  And it is detrimental to current Internet services, except the local cable companies and the few peers they have providing local high speed services.  It should not be put in place.

This is bullshit this has come back into question the huge corporations are ruining America and you fucking communist are allowing it!  We need to keep net neutrality alive and Internet access should be classified as a Title II utility, it's sad that in America we have lower standards for our people than many other respected counties that look up to the USA for guidance.

Please DO NOT revoke Net Neutrality.  Net Neutrality is one of the cornerstones of the internet with respect to fair commerce.  Allowing ISP's to charge web sites for improved bandwidth will dramatically favor the established sites with deeper pockets while at the same time making it impossible for smaller competitors, regardless of whether or not they have a superior product, to effectively serve their customers.  This measure effectively kills healthy competition and destroys the competitive landscape of the internet.

The removal of net neutrality would be extremely harmful to content providers and consumers. It would allow ISPs to arbitrarily raise rates, fees, or charges on popular products without recourse. ISPs, many of whom already charge exorbitant rates, and many of whom enjoy localized monopolies do not in any way require this extra revenue stream. But most offensive in this truly disastrous proposal, is the notion that Internet service is not a utility. We will in a world where access to the Internet is no longer a perk. It is a necessity as fundamental as electricity, or heat. Net Neutrality is fundamental to keeping accessible to Americans. The ISPs should not have the final says over how to content is delivered.

I believe a free and open internet to be essential to a modern democracy.  I tend toward libertarian views, and believe in minimal government interference with American business. 

This approach, however, does not work when businesses face minimal competition.  Allowing internet service providers (henceforth referred to by the common abbreviation 'ISP') to affect their customers' connectivity to select services would be acceptable only in a truly free market, where every customer has the right to choose providers.  Sadly, this is not the case in many places, and allows ISPs to unfairly bias their services based on their own needs rather than serve the customer who pays for service.  

An imperfect, albeit accurate, analogy would be a car company 'C' deciding that their cars would deliberately operate slower or less efficiently when using fuel from one fuel company 'B' , while unlocking additional performance when using fuel from a preferred company 'A'.  Some consumers may choose to accept this, and only buy fuel from the preferred company 'A'.  Others would exercise their right to choose and purchase cars from companies 'D','E', or 'F', or perhaps just not own a car.  In this case, company 'C' would respond to market pressure and change their policies to be more consumer friendly, or lose sales to competition.

In the case of many American markets, the choice is limited to company 'C' or no car at all.  In this instance, the government must weigh the rights of company 'C' vs the rights of millions of individual Americans and small businesses who have to continue operating despite what the government does.  I don't typically champion regulation in any form, but due to the limitations of the marketplace and costs of entry for new upstarts, combined with the essential nature of the service involved, I must implore you to ensure that ISPs are not allowed to interfere with a free and open internet.  

Consider that for many people high speed internet access is as essential to their way of life (necessary for jobs, education, safety, as well as entertainment and leisure) as a car is to someone living in a rural area with no public transportation.  I'm fortunate enough to live in a small city that has multiple ISP options for most areas.  Many surrounding areas are lucky to have one or no option for anything other than extremely costly or limited cellular connections.  Internet service is as essential to modern life as paved roads were immediately after World War 2.  

I thank you for your consideration, and please consider the interests of ALL Americans, not simply large corporations, when making major policy decisions.

We need network neutrality because internet service providers should not be able to pick and choose what websites are fast and what websites are slow. In the digital age, websites make money from people viewing their site, and subsequently viewing their ads. If their website is slow, viewers will leave, and that website will make less money because that website will have fewer views on their ads. This is how ISPs could rig the game if we get rid of network neutrality. And Comcast did this, we know this, this happened just before we made ISPs Title 2 Common Carriers. Comcast was throttling Netflix, and demanding Netflix pay them additional money, which is literally mob-tactics. Ignore the fact that Netflix was already paying their ISPs for a connection to the internet, and consumers were already paying their ISPs for access to the internet, so why the hell should my ISP, e.g. Comcast, be harming my Netflix stream demanding that Netflix pay them extra? Does this not seem wrong? That is like if I pay USPS to send my grandma a letter in the mail, and USPS hands it off to Fedex in Canada, and Fedex stops and holds the letter demanding that I need to pay them additional money for them to deliver the letter to my grandma. I ALREADY PAID YOU ASSHOLES. You could say that in a free market I could just choose a different postal carrier BUT WAIT! WHERE I LIVE I LITERALLY ONLY HAVE ONE OPTION FOR INTERNET! THERE IS NO OTHER OPTION, THERE IS NO COMPETITION! Internet service providers are common carriers, they carry the common packets and and bit and ones and zeros that I use to apply to jobs online, that I use to email my family, that I use to do research for school. They need to remain Common Carriers.

Net neutrality is a fundamental principle of the open web. Without it, innovation will suffer as smaller companies who cannot afford to pay for preferred access will see their content and services disadvantaged to those of larger companies who can afford to pay. The Internet has been largely built by small companies and entrepreneurs, and that was possible only because there was a level playing field with larger companies. The FCC must reject this proposal to undo a fundamental part of what has made the Internet -- and the U.S. economy -- so strong.

The elimination of Net Neutrality rules is a terrible idea that rather clearly and blatantly serves to further line the pockets of the noncompetitive telecom market. The "facts" that Chairman Pai have used to support it have been shown to be twisted and outdated, and serve to show yet again that the current leadership of the FCC cares more about giving telecoms further license to choke the free internet and overcharge consumers.

The internet has become an essential collective medium, as connective, pervasive and critical to our economy, communications (both private and public), and civil engagement as citizens as the very air above our heads. The essence of our skies, the atmosphere itself, enables communication, transportation and trade – connecting cities and peoples throughout our country.

The internet has evolved materially from its origins as a “collection of networks” to a fundamental medium of our culture. It is as pervasive and critical now to the functioning of all corners of academic, spiritual (yes, indeed!), social and business life as the air we breathe. 

Thus I cannot endorse the proposed rulemaking to remove ‘no-throttle’ constraints, which as proposed now would insert into the very medium of the internet opportunity for providers to impede the flow of information in pursuit of profits. I remain in support of strict net neutrality rules, such as those in place today.

I was saddened to hear that you are planning to reclassify internet providers as non-common carriers thus removing the net neutrality previsions along with the other benefits that came with it. While you speak of providing protections through industry measures the truth is, as you are well aware, that the FCC already attempted to protect these necessary freedoms through the use of alternative rule making without using the Title II classifications. This ended in a failure in the courts which required the previous FCC chairman to reclassify the internet providers. In my work I regularly utilize the internet to remote into my office on the weekends so that I can work seven days a week. I am also a heavy user of online video services such as YouTube and Netflix. Prior to the reclassification, I was effected by Verizon's throttling of Netflix which resulted in a worse consumer experience than should have been happening. \n\nWith the removal of these protections, there will be nothing stopping companies such as Verizon from creating services such as a remote software, and then heavily throttling all other competing software forcing me to switch to theirs regardless of how well it competes in other features. If ISPs, such as Verizon, wish for us to use their other services, force them to compete in the free market, with them on an even footing as their competitors.

Killing net neutrality and allowing ISPs to arbitrarily throttle traffic would be disastrous in my line of work. As a software engineer, I rely on a fast, reliable, and uncompromised connection to the internet. When the weather is bad, I work from home, where my residential internet connection often slows me down because of arbitrary limits set in place by my ISP. \n\nMy job also requires that I have access to a wide variety of websites which I cannot predict on a day-to-day basis. My internet connection should deliver these sites to me equally, and having to pay more to access certain sites over others would kill my productivity. Net neutrality promotes innovation and freedom, and the Commission's plans to get rid of net neutrality is an affront to the consumer and plays directly into corporate interests. The internet is for the people, not for Comcast, Verizon, AT&T, et al to gouge the consumer for profit.

From the Canadian CRTC Decision supporting net neutrality:

"If Internet providers price content differently, they are, in a way, influencing you to choose certain content over other.

That’s why we decided that Internet providers must treat data traffic the same, regardless of content.

Internet providers should compete on the quality of their networks, by lowering their prices or increasing data allowances instead of treating certain content differently."

Net neutrality is incredibly important. It is the foundation of what has made the internet the success it's been. It allows startups to compete against established players which truly fosters innovation otherwise an established player can just pay money to non compete fairly. 

An ISP's job is to deliver me the data i ask for, as fast as possible. That's it. That's 100% of their role. That means innovation can come from delivering data faster, giving me more of it, or reducing costs. I am not paying an ISP to filter my content or make choices about what content I can and can't see. That's not innovative.

That would be like if my electric company got to choose what appliances I can and can't power. It makes zero sense. 

The American and Canadian economies are incredibly intertwined, weakening net neutrality will only serve to drag us both down. Keep Title II classification, there is literally zero reasonable reason not to.

"When is 'throttling' harmful to consumers?"

Always.  Preserve Title II, and the rules as they are.  Thank you.

Jonathan

Strong net neutrality rules such as those adopted by your predecessor unambiguously benefit consumers by ensuring a level playing field for competition and increasing choice in content. In fact, without net neutrality, there would be no playing field or content choice, as was clearly demonstrated when Comcast choked off Netflix until Netflix paid Comcast. There appear to be no significant costs associated with net neutrality, as net neutrality has always been how the Internet functioned since its inception. Throttling is nearly always harmful to consumers. As network providers have stated, throttling is not about network management but about creating artificial scarcity to boost revenues. It is particularly pernicious when hidden, as is often the case with "unlimited" plans. Differential prioritization should be prevented as placing the competition and anyone who can't pay in the slow lane is obviously detrimental to consumers. Exceptions already exist, such as the one for telemedicine, so blocking paid prioritization does not harm important latency-sensitive applications and content. In sum, there is nothing about your proposed changes that would help consumers. I urge you to reconsider.

The proposed rule in WC Docket No. 17-108 bears the title of “Restoring Internet Freedom” and claims to do so by removing the Title II common carrier regulations that were put on Internet Service Providers (ISPs) as part of the FCC’s decision in 2015.  The premise that common carrier regulations harms the growth and well being of the Internet is a false conclusion and one only needs to look at the history of Internet connectivity to see the continued need for those protections.

The 1990’s saw the rise of the World Wide Web and the evolution of the Internet as we know it today.  For most consumer users, the connection to the Internet was via a dial-up modem connection over a Title II system, the telephone.  This open and fair playing field allowed the dial-up Internet provider market to thrive and flourish with a range of options from local ISPs to national giants like America OnLine (AOL).  Competition helped to keep prices down and quality up with the open access of the phone system allowing ISPs of all sized an opportunity to enter the market.

With the dial-up technology reaching it’s limit with 56kbps, a new connection  market opened up: broadband.  While broadband heralded in massive increases in speed, it also ushered in a dramatic consolidation of the provider market with only two primary options available: DSL and Cable.  With DSL tied to the local phone provider and cable being a single provider per market situation, the open market under dial-up was now a monopoly or duopoly situation with only one or two high speed options where there could of been dozens with dial-up.  And if you lived in an area where DSL or cable was not available, you were now left behind at the slow 56k speeds of dial-up as the rest of the Internet world moved up to 1Mbps and beyond.

The higher speeds helped to pave the way for new business models such as the digital distribution of content like music, movies and software.  It also saw a continued consolidation of the broadband provider market with companies like Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T dominating the field.  As speeds increased, options for the consumer decreased.  As DSL’s speeds plateaued between 1 and 5 Mbps, telecom providers began moving towards fiber-based solutions such as AT&T’s U-Verse (Fiber to the Node) or FiOS (Fiber to the Home), but availability was limited.  For most users, cable would be the only high-speed broadband options above single digit Mbps speeds.  Wireless and satellite options would appear as alternatives, but while they could reach areas that cable did not, they were often more expensive and did not prove the speed or low latency of a wired or fiber connection.

When the FCC made its 2015 decision to regulate ISPs under Title II, the content delivery market (Netflix, Amazon, iTunes, Hulu, etc.) was hitting a roadblock with the Internet provider market (Comcast, Verizon, etc.).  Video streaming services was increasing the demand for bandwidth, but if performance suffered with one ISP, there was often no choice in the market for an alternative and so ISPs had little incentive to improve their networks.  Wireless solutions such as 3G or LTE were priced to be hostile towards high data usage with data caps and overage fees.  A single movie on Netflix could cause you to go over your monthly data usage and incur huge overage fees.  DSL speeds struggled to keep up with the bandwidth requirements of HD video streams.  While fiber was an alternative to cable, the deployment was limited, and the majority of consumers were left with a single option, cable.  This monopoly position gave the ISPs increasing leverage against content providers where they could extort money in exchange for better performance on their networks.  With the merger of Comcast and NBC/Universal, there was also the danger of an ISP throttling competing video services to favor their own content.  The growing digital distribution market needed protection from abuse in this monopoly/duopoly situation in the high-speed Internet provider market.  This is where the 2015 Title II decision and Net Neutrality came in.  Much in the way that Title II allowed for a thriving and competitive market in the dial-up Internet days of the 1990’s, Title II in 2015 provided a fair playing field for digital content providers in that ISPs could not use their monopoly position to favor one service over another or demand fees from providers or consumers to improve performance.

Competition can help to regulate a market, but there is little choice in the ISP market and Title II is needed to protect content providers and ISP customers the same as with other single provider markets like water or electricity.  Municipalities have created their own high-speed networks, but are limited by local or federal laws from expanding outside their territories or even prevented from existing at all.  Google, a multibillion dollar company, entered the ISP market with Google Fiber, yet it has struggled to expand beyond a few select markets.  This barrier to competition is why we need regulations like Title II to stay in place to keep the incumbent ISPs honest and keep the Internet open with equal access to all.

“Americans cherish a free and open Internet.”  The FCC’s Title II Order protects this.  Please do not take it away.

I and all I know are in strong favor of STRICT Net Neutrality and Privacy regulations governing ISP's. Making use of the internet is not an option anymore, but necessary to serach for and apply for most employment, apply for state and federal services and many other essential functions. Hello, I'm Michael Frisone from Everett, WA.  I'd like to register my opinion in support of Net Neutrality. Chairman Pai's recent decision to move toward a non-Net-Neutrality position of the FCC is a poor decision for the American people and will  in all likelihood result in higher rates, less competition amongst internet service providers, and a severe lack of innovation due to content providers having all the power.  It will also put many companies that rely on the internet at risk as they'll be much more at the mercy of their internet provider offering a truly free and unbiased network.

This is far from a Republican or Democrat issue. Maintaining Net Neutrality will result in fewer regulations as maintaining this single position staves off the inevitable need for future regulation once ISPs begin to abuse their power and gouge customers for every penny they can due to the lack of competition in the retail broadband market and the lack of rules in place to prevent such pricing practices.

Thank you for registering my opinion on the matter. I hope that the FCC will act in accordance with the will of the American People in regards to this matter.

- Michael

As a doctoral candidate in theoretical physics, a Seattle resident, and most importantly, as an American, I am commenting to register my opinion in support of Net Neutrality and wholehearted opposition to Chairman Pai's disastrous decision to undermine: the freedom of information and speech present in an open internet (especially in the age of misinformation and media monopoly); the level playing-field of economic competition and startup potential which has given birth to one of the largest sectors of industry and growth in the United States which is only possible through a neutral internet; and the ability for American broadband customers to have access to affordable internet with the content they desire, not the content they are restricted to unless they pay more in addition to their initial connection payment.

Neither republican nor democrat should be behind this sentiment: it will launch America further behind the world in terms of our freedoms and our ability to both access and create content in the global market. Without Net Neutrality, we will undoubtedly see rampant abuse of power by our limited ISP choices, and customers will face steep price increases for a service inferior to what they had before due to selective service and "fast lane" allotments. The "Restoring Internet Freedom" claims are ostensibly backwards and a sly attempt to trick consumers into believing that regulations which hamper their services are being lifted: Net Neutrality is not about new regulation--it's the way the internet has always been, and the way it needs to remain. 

Without it, ISPs will triple charge consumers: once for connection, once through access to specific content and the speed at which it is accessible, and once again through passed down costs from service providers for large media platforms which will see their costs skyrocket while the ISP's own version of the same service will be greatly undercut, making competition impossible. It's giving the fox the keys to the hen-house, and they will obviously take advantage of the opportunity to make more money at the cost of shutting out emerging startups and charging people for what they already receive for free.

We should not need to learn the right course of action from other first world countries, but we should instead be leading the way on a free and open internet which is as essential as a utility in the modern era as water (and should be treated as such). Do not let the Canadian boarder (as they have just voted in favor of Net Neutrality) become the line which delineates freedom of speech, equality of data, and an open and competitive digital marketplace, from one which is hand-picked to pack the wallets and serve the message of whatever corporation controls one's regional internet service. This is a resoundingly poor decision economically, socially, and politically for the consumer and for the burgeoning digital market, and maintaining, protecting, and promoting Net Neutrality is of utmost importance.
I demand net neutrality. Allowing companies to profit by allowing them to filter internet speed and access is wrong. I demand a free and open internet.

I am writing to voice my opposition to this proposal. I do not want to see the Internet become a feudal domain split between huge, established companies that can pay for better service and innovative startups that cannot. We have YouTube and Netflix today because ISPs there was no two-tier system when they were introduced, and one day perhaps they will be replaced by better services that will need net neutrality protections to let the market choose whether or not they are truly better than their competition.

This is personal; my email and blog are hosted by a small web hosting company. I doubt they could afford to pay the protection money that Comcast, Time Warner, and Verizon would love to charge for their services.

And as for Ajit Pai: I do not understand how a former DOJ Honors Program attorney working in the Antitrust Division can be so obtuse. Our ISPs have NO competition. If you let them deliver ANY new service without fixing that, they will just charge everyone (including me and you!) more for it. If you want free markets, go after the rotten ISPs we all hate so much. A deregulated monopoly is not a free market; I learned that in my very first Econ class.

Thank you.

Internet access is not a luxury, it is an essential tool required for doing business, handling personal finances, and interacting with public services. It should not be controlled by the ISP’s alone. A neutral internet needs to be maintained and access to it should be overseen by an outside body that does not serve the ISP’s interests, but instead serves the interests of end-users. Net neutrality is essential to ensuring equal access to internet content and services. 

Since users have little to no control over who provides their internet service, Internet Service Providers should be neutral in regards to access speeds and charges for that, regardless of the destination and/or the creator of the content. Without outside control over the costs charged by ISP’s and access speeds provided, users are at the mercy of monopolistic ISPs. When ISPs can charge more for content and/or throttle speeds of content derived from entities not owned by the ISP than it charges for its own content, there is no free market.

Without net neutrality enforcement, ISPs will have no motivation to provide equal access to an essential tool. Concentration of internet services in the hands of a few providers who have proven time and again that, without regulation, they will over-charge and under-provide at nearly every opportunity, will be harmful to all of us.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

ISPs have continually shown time and time again they will abuse their customers at every corner and are not interested in furthering development of broadband because they have a literal monopoly and can do as they please because internet is a necessity in the modern world. You are shitting on the American people for the wrong reasons- you should do some more research on how this will affect the average American.

I wish to oppose Ajit Pai's motion to eliminate Net Neutrality rules. I like an internet where Internet Service Providers like Comcast, Verizon, and AT&T are not able to prioritize and block content. I like being able to access everything, rather than letting Internet Service Providers choose what content is available to me on the internet. I like an internet where ISPs are not allowed to pick winners and losers in internet commerce.

We live in a country where ISPs have a documented history of blocking content that they do not wish to service. We need strong regulations to prevent this. I myself live in an apartment whose landlord only offers one choice of internet provider. There is no competition here. If my ISP decides to prevent me from accessing content that it does not like, I have no recourse.

Repealing net neutrality does not advocate freedom for the internet in any way. If anything, it allows ISPs to become gatekeepers to content on the internet. ISPs are allowed to pick winners and losers, and as they are monopoloies in most markets in the country, there is no way to punish this unmistakably anti-consumer behavior. The government must enact and enforce strong net neutrality rules and prevent monopolist ISPs from being allowed to determine which content their consumers can access. This is the real framework that the internet has always operated on and Net Neutrality rules only enforce this existing behavior. It is only in light of recent efforts of ISPs to prioritize and control content on their networks that rules need to take place to prevent the new and anti-consumer behavior of ISPs being allowed to serve as gatekeepers of content on the internet.

As an ordinary consumer, I urge my government to move in a direction of more regulation of those companies who provide access to the Internet. The Internet is not something that is optional to have, rather it is fast becoming necessary for all residents of the United States. Rescinding net neutrality rules is not in the best interest of ordinary citizens. The FCC seems to be working on behalf of the Internet Service Provides and not on behalf of all US citizens. I don't like it and will be worried if the FCC moves forward with dropping net neutrality rules.

I urge you not to dismantle the Title II status currently regulating the ISPs.  There is no benefit to consumers if you remove the protections that are currently in place.  I implore you to leave the current Net Neutrality rules in place and keep the FCC as the regulating body for the ISPs.  Do NOT allow paid prioritization as it will not benefit the consumer, but will only help the ISPs.

column7: I urge the FCC to PRESERVE NET NEUTRALITY.  The broadband services in the US are rarely competitive, large cable providers intentionally carve up the country to avoid competition with each other.  Without net neutrality they have the power to pick winners and losers coming across the internet.  I already paid for my internet services, they should not be allowed to double bill the web companies to allow/prioritize traffic.  I already paid for those bits to be delivered according to my service agreement no matter who serves the bits!\n\nKEEP NET NEUTRALITY

Trying to remove Title II classification will hurt the every day consumer and slow down competition as large IPS are given more power to solidify an oligopoly market. Title II allows the internet to remain open and prompts fair competition between businesses of all sizes.

The draft seeks comment on the analysis in Paragraph 27. This analysis purports to show that broadband Internet service is an information service because it provides users the "capability for generating, acquiring, storing, transforming, processing, retrieving, utilizing, or making available information via telecommunications." The argument given is that broadband Internet service allows users to do all these things. However, this is not the same as providing the capability to do these things. To see why, consider that providing users Internet services over dialup phone lines also allows users to do all these things; but the phone lines themselves are telecommunications services, not information services. Why? Because providing the user dialup Internet, by itself, does not provide them the capability to do all these things. That capability is provided by the endpoints: the users' computers, and the computers hosting the Internet services that the users connect to.\nExactly the same is true of broadband Internet services provided by ISPs: by themselves, they do not provide users the capability to do all these things. They only provide connections between computers at the endpoints that provide those capabilities. It is the services provided by the Internet hosts that users connect to that are "information services". The broadband Internet services that allow users to connect to those hosts are telecommunications services, and should be regulated as such.\nISPs object to analyses like the one above because they claim that they also provide the actual information services--in other words, they also provide Internet hosts that function as email servers, web servers, etc. But it is obvious that those services are separate from the broadband connection services provided by those same ISPs, because users can make use of the latter without making use of the former at all. I am such a user: I use the broadband Internet connection provided by my ISP, but I do not use any of the information services they provide; I do not use their email, their web hosting, etc. I use other Internet hosts provided by other companies for those services. The fact that ISPs offer information services as well as telecommunications services does not make their telecommunications services into information services; an ISP's choice of business model cannot change the nature of a particular service it provides. Broadband Internet connections are obviously a telecommunications service, and should be regulated as such, regardless of what other services ISPs would like to bundle with them. The FCC should continue to regulate broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service.

I urge the FCC in the strongest terms possible to REJECT the proposed and deliberately misleading RESTORING INTERNET FREEDOM NPRM issued by Chairman Ajit Pai. I recognize this proposal for what it is, a blatent attempt by ISP to perpetuate their monopolies. It is a blatant attack on the American Consumer, and it must be rejected our of hand.

Before you get to read my "Canned" comment below, I want to go on record to say that the only entities that will achieve "Internet Freedom" are the providers who rake us users over the coals as much as  they can, with a big fat smile on their faces.\nAnd here I go: \nParagraph 82 asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Isn’t it possible they could do this again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Thanks for reading my comment.

This is not a good plan. Giving ISP's the ability to throttle the access speeds of websites and content providers simply based on arbitrary reasoning is a slippery slope. The 'freedom' that this plan has decided to pursue is only freedom in name. It would allow companies to restrict or at least greatly reduce access to whatever content they deem unworthy (or too poor to pay whatever fees the ISP's decide to charge for decent speeds), and is frankly a slap in the face to the consumer.  The whole idea of Section 3 (Ending public utility status) is not good. In today's economy, if you don't have internet access, you likely aren't able to hold a job because of it. Access to the Internet has become a necessity if you want to be a successful member of this capitalist society, much like water and electricity. \nAnd as for Section IV, the whole 'self policing' idea? Have you ever spoken to ISP reps on they phone? They can't be trusted to police their own customer service, let alone their whole industry.

Dear FCC, While I respect the intention of furthering internet innovation and improvement for all consumers,
I will not stand by this bill for the sole reason of taking away provisions put in place to ensure consumers are not ripped
off by ISPs and have their internet throttled just because they cannot afford higher speeds. The internet is no longer a
simple luxury that can be continued to be used to exploit higher and higher costs from consumers, especially from ISPs
that are constantly looking for ways to force the consumer into nonnegotiable, nondisputable agreements for their NECESSARY
internet access, speeds, and content. ISPs have continued to demonstrate no interest in competing with each other nor 
innovate in any meaningful away, with some ISPs being the exception. If ISPs don't wish to expand their coverage and continue to extort consumers who may only have one choice of ISP in their area, then I will not stand by any decision to help them trample upon the right of the consumer to lose quality to such a necessary part of their daily living.

I find it morbidly ironic that this docket is called the "Restoring Internet Freedom" proposal. As a customer, I would like the freedom to choose between many service providers. This choice is all but an illusion if service providers do not have a baseline of neutrality delivering content over the network. The FCC is an administration set up by the people and should use its regulatory power to help the citizens. This newfound "Internet Freedom" would only benefit the rich as well as internet providers, who still to this day provide absolutely horrible service. The Internet should be regulated like a common carrier and should be a utility. Ideally, we should have municipalities setting up open fiber networks that would allow multiple service providers to tie into it to allow capitalism to do its work having multiple companies competing for business as the utility itself would be owned by the people, instead of having a stranglehold duopoly on the infrastructure. I do not support this proposal. I don't believe that these will actually be read, but Ajit Pai, should step down in shame for being a shill for the telecoms.

The proposed changes are not "restoring freedom" to anyone. It should be very clear that the proposals made are harmful to individuals, harmful to the market, and harmful to the growth of our nation. The net MUST remain neutral, open, and free from interference of any kind if we want to maintain the freedom of privacy and communication tht we currently enjoy.

Net Neutrality is important and must be upheld.  Do not allow corporations to restrict fair access to the internet to only those willing to pay an unnecessary premium.  This government is supposed to be for the protection of all citizens equally, not a means for a wealthy few to take advantage of the rest.  Internet service providers in the US must be reigned in and made to conduct their businesses fairly.

Internet access is a right and thus falls under public utility standards. Allowing the manipulation of access through private companies throttling or whatever is a violation of that right.  Do your job and guarantee equal access!  Secure all citizen rights!

I oppose any actions that would undermine a free and open internet. I am a web developer and do business entirely online, it will put small businesses and start ups at a huge disadvantage if the internet is turned into a pay to win system with fast lanes going to only those who can afford it. This goes against the entire intent of the internet! It's supposed to be a place where anyone can freely and openly exchange information and access information. Do not weaken internet freedom protections! Everyone deserves a free and open internet.

Keep net neutrality. It's no secret that Pai and the other Republicans on the FCC are paid for by the telecommunications industry (or are complete and utter blowhards - both are possible in this administration). Net neutrality under Title II is vital to continued consumer/citizen freedom, entrepreneurial creativity, and business growth. It doesn't fall under FTC jurisdiction, and you've already given away so many consumer protections under false pretenses (or stupid ones - again, both are possible). So the question isn't, "How can you fight for rights and protections for Americans and American businesses?" but instead, "Will you fight for their rights?"

I’m worried that the protections that are in place will be weakened if we change the way they’re enforced. I would support a new regulation style if it guarantees the same or better protections, but not if we lose any.

As a Computer Science major and a tech enthusiast, I can confidently say that I support title II regulations over internet service providers.  A web with net neutrality is how the internet is intended to be run, and title II will ensure that for generations to come.

Comment
On 4/26/17, Ajit Pai has decided to hold a vote on ending net neutrality and the classification of internet service providers and especially cable companies and telecoms (e.g. Verizon, at&t, comcast, cox, etc.) as common carriers under title ii. Instead he wants to classify them as a title I information service. Unfortunately, Ajit Pai is wrong just like he was on ending our privacy rights. ISPs are a common carrier just like the telephone companies. Their sole purpose is to carry our internet traffic from our homes, cell phones and businesses to the internet. Just like telephone companies do the same for voice calls. ISPs provide no useful information service to consumers. Ending net neutrality is going to reduce competition and substantially increase costs to the American public especially for services like Netflix, Hulu, and YouTube. Ending net neutrality will allow Verizon and Comcast and similar companies push their own services like video streaming over companies like Hulu, Netflix, and YouTube because they can price them out of the market. This will DESTROY competition on the internet and increase the isp/telco monopoly. This is just another example of how corrupt Ajit Pai is. He basically violating a federal court ruling and lying to congress and the American people about the impact and need for this change. Federal courts have already determined that ISPs are common carriers under title II. He said in his speech that the title II common carrier determination cost jobs and investment. This is a complete lie. The teleco are spending billions in their infrastructure and net neutrality has had no material impact on the telcos or their investments or their profits! Every major cable company and telco has INCREASED their infrastructure spending including after net neutrality took affect. Ajit Pai has tendency to state things as fact without the objective neutral party data to back it up. He did the same thing when he lied about the isp privacy rights change. He made up facts and lied to congress. He is doing it again now. Ajit Pai is former employee and lawyer for Verizon and this change DIRECTLY benefits his former employer and is buddies in the telco industry. What Ajit Pai is doing is unethical and shows how utterly corrupt the FCC management has become. They are ignoring what the American people want and doing exactly what their former employers want. So much for draining the swamp of the corrupt and dishonest politicans and political appointees in Washington. DoJ should investigate the FCC management for potential conflicts of interest and lying to congress. Undoing the common carrier determination for isp/telco is wrong for America. These companies are already de facto monopolies in most states. Getting rid of net neutrality will only make a bad situation worse.

During FCC press conferences and published statements this week, Ajit Pai said was no evidence of the need for regulating throttling, blocking, and paying for transport. Apparently Ajit lives under a rock because all the major internet companies including Netflix, YouTube and many others have complained bitterly about ISP demanding payment for transport to the consumer while Comcast and Verizon market their own video streaming services to the same consumer. This is the textbook definition of a monopoly and any competent lawyer would know that. But that would assume Ajit Pai was a competent lawyer....the only thing he is competent in is screwing the American public's privacy and internet freedom so his former employer Verizon and it his friends in the telecom  industry rake in billions of dollars in profits on the backs hard working Americans.

Ending net neutrality is not about increasing internet freedom and choice - it is about enshrining Americans with bigger ISP monopolies. Ajit Pai is an incompetent and corrupt chairman of the FCC and is knowingly lying to Congress and the American public. 

Even NCTA's, a cable industry lobbyist, own data at https://www.ncta.com/industry-data completely contradicts Ajit Pai statements about net neutrality costing jobs, hurting innovation, and reducing investment. Since 1996 the cable industry has invested $250 BILLION in infrastructure and it has increased EVERY year and they have added thousands of new jobs for a total of 2.7 million.

Wow....how about those numbers... it is a shame you are more interested in listening to FreedomWorks's fake facts than the real ones.

The present notion of treating the internet like any other public-service utility seems exactly right. The internet is ubiquitous and essential, and companies should not be allowed to create premium-access levels that only benefit their own bottom line. As for Paragraph 82, which asks for input on whether throttling should be regulated, yes it should be, for the reason cited above and because of ISPs' past actions which required court intervention. I’m also concerned about mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap they throttle only those sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. Thanks very much for reading my comment.

Like America's business backbone is small business, so to with the Internet's base is small, individual websites and small businesses. We need the protections of title II and net neutrality to protect the small businesses and individuals. You cannot expect large businesses to give up a dominant role just to give the small guy a chance, it would never happen.

“Consumers want an open internet that doesn’t discriminate on content and protects free speech and consumer privacy,” Republican lawmakers have recently stated.

This is exactly what the current net neutrality rules enforce and they should remain in place. Removing these rules would allow broadband providers to pick and choose which online services and businesses can succeed. Any competitors to the many conflicts of interest the broadband providers have would find themselves unable to compete.

Google, Facebook, Amazon, Wikipedia, Netflix and thousands of other companies which make up many of the 6.7million+ jobs in the tech industry all stand with keeping net neutrality. They, and all the jobs and investment they have created, would not be able to exist if broadband providers had free reign to pick and choose which services are able to succeed and which are pushed to the side.

During oral arguments in Verizon v. FCC in 2013, judges asked whether the phone giant would favor some preferred services, content or sites over others if the court overruled the agency’s existing open internet rules. Verizon counsel Helgi Walker had this to say: “I’m authorized to state from my client today that but for these rules we would be exploring those types of arrangements.”

Year after year, providers have been shown to abuse the ability to control traffic for their own gains, even when they have specifically agreed not to. There is no sign that they have the desire or ability to change, and the rules must remain the same as they are today to ensure consumers are protected.

Unlike our roadway system, which is almost entirely publicly funded and therefore open to all equally, the internet infrastructure is largely privately owned, particularly the last mile to the customer.

The FCC quite properly wants to let businesses make their own decisions, without too much regulation. But in the case of Net Neutrality, business interests collide, between ISPs on one side and content creators on the other. 

We know how to solve this problem. We solved it with electricity, with gas, with land line telephone. The Internet needs a Public Utility business model for the last mile. 

Here in Houston, Texas, I can buy electricity from any of a number of different providers. The wires to my house are maintained by a Utility, who just move the power as efficiently as they can from the wind farm to my house.

We need the same model for Internet access. My ISP should do nothing more than deliver bytes to me as fast as possible. It’s up to me to decide where those bytes come from in the larger Internet. This Internet Utility would be prevented by law from even looking at the content of my network traffic except under strict circumstances. It wouldn't offer email accounts or cloud storage or other services, just bytes as fast as possible.

Service Providers should not control the last mile to my house.
Net neutrality is essential to a democracy and any attempt to rescind it shows irresponsibility.

Hello, I am writing today out of extreme concern with this foolish action the new head of the FCC is suggesting. I can think of new reason to repel net neutrality except to further line the deep pockets of ISPs who refuse to compete. I am a strong proponent for Net Neutrality I wrote in favor of it before it was made so and I shall support it if you make the mistake of attacking the American Consumer and businesses. I work at a "Managed Service Provider" and we support several clients, Manufacturers, Woman's Shelters, City Governments, and Scientific Research firms. and let me tell you there is no division within the rankings of my company ISPs are looking to make a buck and the quality of service rendered isn't even a second thought. I'm not saying some don't try, but we've had ISPs that allowed emergency rape counseling facility's to repeatedly lose service due to neglected infrastructure. They offered to charge us fees in order to make alternative arrangements while the services were down. For example when their DSL provider lost service my company investigated alternatives sadly there were NONE, so we reached out with the ISP in question and sought assistance in improving reliability. The "best" they would offer was a add-on service for $15 a month to allow multiple rapid call routes to be places. A Suicide hotline and Rape Counseling service funded with public/government funds was told they could pay extra to get the emergency number routed through the online interface, instead of having to call in and wait upwards of 45 minutes before being connected to a human being; which would then route you to hopefully but rarely the correct department to make those changes. In a single quarter they lost service for hours at a time 4 times and once for two entire days. It's possible someone committed suicide, it's possible someone was raped and never got counseling. That's just a moral story, when you start to calculate losses from profit earning clients, we are talking about serious losses for the American people, American Business and thus the US Government through Tax revenue.

I could go on for hours about personal experiences, I could rant about how my ISP has attempted to charge me over a dozen times for "leasing" a modem I bought from Amazon. I could complain about how my speeds aren't even 1/4 the advertised speed unless you use the ISPs speed check tool.

When Ajit Pai betrayed the entire american public by announcing his support in repealing laws protecting American consumers from being spied upon by ISPs I felt a righteous fury similar to that of someone who's God has been attacked. The rules Tom Wheeler put in place requiring Opt-In consent allowed for us as customers to take advantage of any offers to lesson the cost of service, etc by opting in to allowing our data to be used was the correct decision. When I choose an ISP I have 1-2 choices, those choices are Cable or inferior DSL, I live in a semi-large city and this is the national status quo. Opting in to the advertising program an ISP might offer is a lot like using Google, I have several choice available I can Google, I can Bing, I can even scan the internet myself and look for website; we even have DuckDuckGo! However a website is a destination like Mc Donalds, while the ISP is "like a series of pipes/tubes" as one congressman once put it. It's the means in which we travel, like roads or a car. It is clearly an entirely different thing all together to choose to go to Google's website, read the EULA and use their services vs hiring one of two ISPs and having all traffic being monitored.

While I respect the Democratic process I will say this, I feel betrayed by the current Administration they promised to "drain the swamp" not inject it with ISP run off. Furthermore how on earth does a former ISP Lapdog (Tom Wheeler) end up being the bigger protector of American/business interests then a republican? WTF???? Pai is a terrorist in disguise trying to ruin what makes america great, Freedom of Expression, but once Muslim and Atheist controlled ISPs are free to throttle web services they don't like and crush innovation we will all be harmed and I will be filing my patents in Germany.  

Also please note the ending was satire, I don't actually think Islam controls ISPs but one day they could just like ultra-right wing Christians or Nazi's could, any group could exert their insane will over innocent people because you decided ISP freedom was more important then protecting the citizens and businesses that make America. Not a single News Paper, legitimate journal, or tech site has shown anything other then the willingness and need to fight this insanity and I will give my life if need be to protect the right to knowledge. Holy Wars have been fought over less, please don't instigate a war.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.
