The FCC's decision to overturn Title II rules applied to ISP's is very disturbing and shows a trend of federal entities making decisions that will hurt consumers and empower businesses. With this decision there will be less competition as large ISP's won't allow small broadband providers to use existing infrastructure, they will push their own products over that of a 3rd party (Verizon or Comcast on demand content vs. Netflix) and they will limit the consumers ability to access their service (data caps with overage fees and speed caps after a certain usage). The idea of net neutrality is a staple of the internet; people should be able to access anything that is available as much as they want without fear of being charged more than their monthly bill by their ISP or by being limited because they are using a 3rd party application over an ISP's application. I strongly disagree with the FCC's decision and would like them to keep our current Title II and Net Neutrality rules that allow more competition between broadband and service providers which give consumers a choice that fits their budget and lifestyle.
Refer to Attachment(s).
Please protect net neutrality. Please, so information won't be stifled.
Seriously why don't you guys just leave the internet alone already.

The last time companies were allowed to police themselves, nothing amazing happened, rather the opposite. Currently, cable companies essentially have geographic monopolies, and without competition and without outside policing, these companies can easily become tyrants. I refuse to believe in the goodwill of profit-driven companies -- no sane entity trying to get money will truly hold itself back from achieving profit at its own expense. Losing net neutrality rules is a harm to all Americans that only serve to enhance companies that do not grow because doing so is expensive and unnecessary in the current market, and will only get worse in a market without rules.

Overturning the 2015 Net Neutrality order is pretty goddamn evil and you're a bunch of cynical bastards if you think we should trust ISPs to regulate themselves. Internet service is a natural monopoly and should be a public utility. I realize the 2015 order wasn't that - but this is going in the opposite direction.\n\nYour terrible new laws will certainly go through, but will be immediately challenged in court. I hope you lose.

The internet is a utility to myself and many others, removing net neutrality will make troubleshooting network issues incredibly more difficult. How do you know if your customer's issues are due to their ISP or some other network along the way if each is allowed to prioritize or block network traffic as they see fit?\nAll the benefits of traffic shaping and prioritization can be done on peoples home routers, but this requires a "utility like" internet connection in order to work properly.  \nRemoving the FCC title 2 protection of network neutrality will cost companies more in overhead and cause more confusion and frustration for consumers.

I am a concerned citizen living in a rural area with a single high speed internet provider available. Having reviewed a summary of the notice of proposed rulemaking, I am highly concerned and find myself opposed to nearly all points. 

Under the current rules, there are currently no notable issues with latency and while pricing is higher than ideal, prices per unit bandwidth have actually dropped for the first time in several years under the net neutrality rules after continuously climbing for many years. 

As we have highly limited competition in ISPs, throttling services that won't or can't afford to pay their fees creates the risk of limiting competitiveness on the internet. At the moment I use my broadband to stream video due to poor TV reception, download resources to learn new skills, share important documents with contacts in a larger city, locate new equipment through several channels, and maintain an online presence across multiple platforms. If my ISP were to pick and choose which services worked well and which didn't, it would limit my ability to competitively pick between different services for all these activities. 

Given the reality of broadband competitiveness, I don't see how consumer protection and a rollback of the 2015 rules can be achieved simultaneously.

How does the rule benefit consumers, and what are its costs?
The rule benefits consumers by ensuring their internet is served on a level playing field. Under the rule ISPs are not allowed to favor their own content, disrupting their competitors. This "equality of content" is what has fostered the free and open internet. It is pro-competitive, and this is a direct benefit to consumers.


When is 'throttling' harmful to consumers?
When it allows ISP to degrade the service of their competitors, creating an uneven choice between unthrottled and throttled content. For Example, Comcast could allow their own network video services to connect to consumers without throttling, while throttling Netflix. Please note: this is not a hypothetical, this has actually happened before. This kind of throttling stiffes competition and creates monopolies by ensuring only one service works at an acceptable level.

Does the no-throttling rule prevent providers from offering broadband Internet access service with differentiated prioritization that benefits consumers?
No, because differentiated prioritization does not benefit consumers. It stiffles competition, which is bad for consumers.

Does the no-throttling rule harm latency-sensitive applications and content?
There is no evidence that it does.

Leave net neutrality alone. The internet is a vital resource, and unfortunately, wireline ISP's do not compete. They run virtual monopolies, and monopolies always turn to consumer hostile practices to increase their revenue. It's not like you can pick from a variety of ISP's. No. At most, you have 2 choices, and one of those is probably slow DSL. So we put up with consumer hostile practices because we have no choice. With the removal of net neutrality, you will be paving the way for ISP's to make internet decisions for us. They would have free reign to block or throttle services that they don't like, or that don't pay a fee.  We've already seen throttling behavior from ISP's such as Comcast blocking bit torrent traffic. They will not self regulate. This is a bad joke if you think they will. Please keep the internet free and open, as it has operated for the past few decades. ISP's already have too much power over their captive audience. Do something for consumers for once, instead of more giveaways to your former employer. I have no doubt all the suggestions you receiver in support for NN will be ignored, though.

Allowing an internet service provider (herein referred to as ISP) to throttle internet traffic only restores freedom to the ISP itself and will likely have the adverse affect of taking away freedom from the very consumer that the FCC is tasked with protecting.  I consider the internet to be as useful as other basic utilities like electricity or water.  It wouldn't make sense for electric company to tell me that my microwave oven could get lots of electricity while my electric car could only get a trickle.  In the same it doesn't make sense to empower ISPs to determine how much bandwidth any particular service should get5.  Beyond that ISPs advertise and commit to consumers to provide a certain amount of bandwidth (generally measure in megabits per second or kilobits per second) so it would be disingenuous and false of them to then not provide that amount in certain cases.

By allowing ISPs to throttle internet traffic they will be incentivized to throttle competitors and not their own services.  This will reinforce the lack of competition that already exists in the telecommunication space giving consumers less choice, removing competition and ultimately hurting consumers by allowing ISPs to raise prices and provide lower quality service.  It would be easy to see how a ISP would throttle Netflix to a point that it was unusable while leaving their own video service working perfectly, essentially removing the consumers choice.

Comcast, Charter, Verizon, AT&T and other ISPs do not often innovate; except perhaps by trying to find new ways to provide lower quality services at higher prices.  The real innovators are startup companies with big dreams and small budgets.  They need a level playing field (one provided by net neutrality) to have a better chance to succeed and be the next big thing.  By removing net neutrality large telcos like those mentioned at the beginning of this paragraph could squash small companies that rely on the internet by throttling those small companies connection to consumers to the point that consumers would find the service unusable.

Please do not allow corporate interests to rule the internet.  The internet is a place for the free exchange of information and ideas and should remain as open as possible.

The notion that this is "restoring freedom" is absurd at best.  High speed access to information is an absolute necessity in this day and age - and should be treated as such.  The moment you allow internet service providers to charge content creators (on top of the money they charge me - the consumer), is the moment you break what makes the internet worthwhile.

Small companies (the entrepreneur, startup, small businessman that the GOP is supposed to be looking out for) will have a much harder time getting off the ground.  How will a new streaming site compete with YouTube when they can't possibly start on a level playing field?

What happens when the ISPs start throttling or blocking access to sites for politicians that don't align fully with their corporate interests?

Please, look inside yourself for any shred of human decency and do the right thing for once.  Please.

As a US citizen, I am strongly opposed to the proposal to remove the current rules for Net Neutrality that prohibit ISPs for blocking, throttling and prioritizing traffic.  We have already seen similar problems around peering agreements, where telcos that provide both cable and internet services  have hampered competition by demanding to be paid twice (once by the consumer and once by the provider) in order to carry competitors' data, such as for services like Netflix.  This is a classic conflict of interest, where they are able to leverage their existing dominant position as an internet provider to unfairly disadvantage a competitor to the cable television side of their business.  

ISPs should not be able to shut out competition by requiring customers to pay extra to access some websites vs others.  

Small businesses shouldn't be subject to pay-to-play rules in order to be able to compete on a level playing field, but if we allow ISPs to selectively throttle, block or prioritize traffic, those that can't pay extra will be shunted to the slow lane and stand little chance against larger entrenched business, greatly limiting choices for the end consumer.  

The internet has been an incredible source of innovation and economic growth, especially for the United States.  I respectfully request that we don't lose that by giving up one of its founding principles, that all sites are equally accessible, whether they're authored by a small mom & pop business, or multi-billion dollar corporation.   
Let the market decide, not the network carrier.

The proposed rule making doesn't adequately enforce freedom on the Internet, it only grants freedom allowing Internet Service Providers to restrict access to the open Internet. ISPs are not the creators of the Internet, they're the services used by US residents to access the Internet. By giving special permissions and access to ISPs, the FCC is creating a walled garden around the open Internet through which most US residents won't have options to circumvent. This action will hamper the US' ability to innovate in the global market and will set our economy behind other technologically advanced nations.

There's nothing here that helps consumers at all. Instead it panders to internet monopolies and oligopolies that want to charge consumers more for the same content the receive now. Also, it allows ISPs to pick winners and losers in terms of speed provided for startups.

The barbaric conclusion that throttling access to websites or services could potentially prove beneficial to customers, is blasphemy. Has anyone a part of this commission encountered or researched the real life consequences of such? My first personally experienced, consumer-hostile throttling occurred in 2014/15 when Netflix was throttled by several ISPs. The only alleviation was a forced - simply frivolous - collocation of Netflix servers at ISP data centers. http://lmgtfy.com/?q=netflix+throttling+2014\n\nKeep Net Neutrality intact.
Refer to Attachment(s).

I run a small internet publishing site.  I need all internet providers to provide my content when requested to be competitive with the large internet publishing websites.  Please protect us small publishers.  Without government protection we will be destroyed by fees from the internet providers.
As a consumer and a small business owner there is no way that rolling back the net neutrality requirements will help me other than to ultimately increase the price of my internet connection.

Please do not go through with dismantling Net Neutrality. Removing these restrictions on ISPs does nothing to benefit the people of America and only stand to benefit big corporations. These rules were put in place for a reason and the people have spoken before about how they feel about them!

Thank you,
John

KEEP TITLE 2. Pai is an unprincipled monster who purports to champion "the consumer" while taking donations from the biggest ISP lobbying groups. Net Nuetrality is essential for the free exchange of ideas across international borders, and he seeks to hamstring that for his own financial gain. Fuck you Pai.

The draft seeks comment on the analysis in Paragraph 27. This analysis purports to show that broadband Internet service is an information service because it provides users the "capability for generating, acquiring, storing, transforming, processing, retrieving, utilizing, or making available information via telecommunications." The argument given is that broadband Internet service allows users to do all these things. However, this is not the same as providing the capability to do these things. To see why, consider that providing users Internet services over dialup phone lines also allows users to do all these things; but the phone lines themselves are telecommunications services, not information services. Why? Because providing the user dialup Internet, by itself, does not provide them the capability to do all these things. That capability is provided by the endpoints: the users' computers, and the computers hosting the Internet services that the users connect to.\nExactly the same is true of broadband Internet services provided by ISPs: by themselves, they do not provide users the capability to do all these things. They only provide connections between computers at the endpoints that provide those capabilities. It is the services provided by the Internet hosts that users connect to that are "information services". The broadband Internet services that allow users to connect to those hosts are telecommunications services, and should be regulated as such.\nISPs object to analyses like the one above because they claim that they also provide the actual information services--in other words, they also provide Internet hosts that function as email servers, web servers, etc. But it is obvious that those services are separate from the broadband connection services provided by those same ISPs, because users can make use of the latter without making use of the former at all. I am such a user: I use the broadband Internet connection provided by my ISP, but I do not use any of the information services they provide; I do not use their email, their web hosting, etc. I use other Internet hosts provided by other companies for those services. The fact that ISPs offer information services as well as telecommunications services does not make their telecommunications services into information services; an ISP's choice of business model cannot change the nature of a particular service it provides. Broadband Internet connections are obviously a telecommunications service, and should be regulated as such, regardless of what other services ISPs would like to bundle with them. The FCC should continue to regulate broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service.

Good People -

I cannot see how Internet Neutrality is technically hurting us consumers and taxpayers. The internet IS a utility and the big telecoms do not want to be regulated  as a utility. In effect you are letting the telecom giants have their way - and we, the paying public will continue to pay more and more. The telecom giants' arguments that they cannot spend more on their networks is fallacious (read "bogus") based on their huge investments SINCE net neutrality was put into effect. I insist on internet regulation as a utility to include net neutrality. Once the fiber is laid capacity can be increased without laying more fiber - upgrading the fiber equipment deployed to use the fiber is all that's needed.. That's already been proven. 

Thanks for the opportunity to comment - Leon

The internet must remain open and neutral. Preserve net neutrality to ensure this. Internet service providers cannot be trusted to operate fairly and give every website and every user an equal experience. Their goal is profit, and they already frequently hold monopolies in service areas. With the proliferation of Internet use throughout our society, we need net neutrality in order for our businesses to stay viable. We need net neutrality to ensure that special interest groups do not begin to control even the far corners of the internet.\n\nKilling net neutrality benefits no one but ISP CEOs. Saying otherwise is disingenuous in the extreme.

I would like to voice my opposition to the "Restoring Internet Freedom Act." I am in favor of Net Neutrality and wish to keep government regulations in place to prevent abuse by ISP companies.
NO NO NO on this Bill...

Regarding the Restoring Internet Freedom FCC proposed ruling I have the following negative view that this proposal will not in fact benefit the freedom of the Internet or restore it but rather will transform it into the equivalent of commercial television for all intensive purposes thus destroying a vast public commons for the free exchange if ideas.

There are many theories and predictions of how the  FCC is simultaneously allowing or proposing regulations allowing free streaming while also simultaneously ending net neutrality.  It seems like a complicated compromise between a free internet and freedom from data fees for streaming videos via wireless.

It is not complicated at all.  The dual FCC rulings will allow advertisers to pay for wireless traffic while simultaneously ending ISPs obligation to host websites for free.  Thus turning the internet into TV.  That is a correct assessment of what is being proposed by the FCC.  THE INTERNET WILL BECOME TV.

It is a rather horrible end to the internet.  It is quickly coming to an end with an FCC decision on May 18th to end net neutrality and allow commercial enterprises to pay for free TV on your web browser but not much else.

Verizon is anticipating the end of email by discontinuing their email service on May 18th.  The date is no coincidence.  They are ending their free email services and are preparing for a fee based email service to replace it.

It is likely we will be charged a fee if we want to send an email shortly but you will get to watch Netflix for free on your Smartphone entitling you to while away your time watching TV but being charged a hefty fee if you want to have an ISP host your website.

The internet is about to be turned into TV for free while we will face stiff charges if you are a business who wants to have a website hosted by an ISP.  The proposal will turn the internet into an exact model of commercial TV where access comes with a hefty price tag but corporate advertisers who pay for entertainment and commercial news and other corporate media outlets pay for it and provide it for free.

The internet should be a public commons where information is freely accessible.  The price ISPs charge for access to the internet is enough to support a business model as public utilities supplying access to the internet as well as hosting email services.

There is a purely driven profit motive here where ISPs will charge other email providers with access fees which will likely result in user fees from alternative email providers.  It is no coincidence that Verizon plans to end free email services on May 18th which is the date of the FCC ruling on the Restoring Internet Freedom.

It will indeed restore freedom to charge for access to the internet by ISPs who will reap profits from the ruling.  Everyone else will end up paying for it.

The FCC has been charged with regulating the telecommunication industry and to enact regulations which will ensure that massive commercial telecom's protect the right to free speech.  The Internet has provided up until now such a means for individual citizens to voice free speech and have the opportunity for their voices to be heard.

The Restoring Internet Freedom proposal will accomplish the exact opposite of that for citizens while guaranteeing freedom fro ISPs to charge for access to an internet which is already charged for by ISPs.

The Internet should continue to be a paid service where ISPs charge for a gateway to the internet but not to charge for access based on who is willing to pay extra fees for communication which is the basic feature of the internet like telephone and cellphone communication is not charged special fees for placing calls or sending emails.

In closing, the Restoring Internet Freedom proposed ruling is a euphemism for charging for access and ending internet freedom.  The title of the proposal has all the hallmarks of a deceptive rouse to disguise the real intention of the proposed ruling and is evident corruption and dishonest brokering by federal agencies which should be investigated and prosecuted as dis-serving the public interest that the FCC is charged to protect.

Dear FCC, I am writing this comment in order to express my strong and vehement opposition to the Restoring Internet Freedom proceeding. The reversal of Obama-era Net Neutrality rules would result in cable companies gaining huge amounts of freedom and reaping enormous profits, at the expense of not only internet consumers, but all small business owners who use the internet in order to promote and grow their business. This move would transform the internet from an open and free framework to a highly restricted one controlled by corporations; free exchange of information would be replaced by increased fees in order to see websites we want. The modern economy was founded on, and depends on, an open and free internet. Do not make the drastic mistake of undoing so much progress and taking us backwards by 25 years.

Net neutrality should be a human right. Is that the kind of country you want to help create?

Net Neutrality allows for small business development without the risk of larger corporations buying up the bandwidth available in areas.  Currently we have a system in place that allows for development of all businesses at any level and is a content rich environment.  Limiting the size of business that can compete will limit the content and availability of information.

Allowing the businesses that we pay to have access to the internet the ability to regulate what and how much of a site we access would end up with the same situation we have with cable TV.  A monopoly of businesses that control the content of what we view and how we view it.  

Once the ability to regulate is handed down it would be abused as it was similarly in many situations prior to the rule making.  Once the companies have the ability to throttle the internet on a large scale there would be a very low chance of turning back the situation.  

Those are my comments that are brief for this situation but I have several other reasonable arguments against removing this rule.  I would also say that this situation is similar to removing the privacy rule recently, someone is lobbying hard because their is significant monies to be gained by throttling content.
"Internet Freedom" is Net Neutrality and it should stay as it is.

The purpose of government regulation is to maintain a competitive environment which encourages innovation.   The current Title II classification of Internet Service Providers  as Common Carriers provides  a competitive environment that benefits economic development, allowing new businesses with innovative ideas to compete on an equal footing.  

Removing the Common Carrier status from the Internet Service Providers would allow them to become gatekeepers to innovation, leveraging their position as carriers to financially disadvantage any new business.  This leverage could be used to weaken potential competitors enough to buy out or bankrupt them, or to take over a new emerging market by leveraging their position to under price the traffic of the competition.

Internet access is essential for commerce, financial and personal communication, and increasingly , public expression.  It is no longer a luxury, it is a utility and it should be regulated as such.  

In this day and age it is unthinkable that the cost of a phone call would vary depending upon the identity of the person or business being called and their business relationship to the phone company.  Why is it acceptable that the modern essential business utility of the Internet vary in cost based on the website accessed?  

I oppose removing Title II classification of Internet Service Providers as Common Carriers.
The US is the champion of the internet, what you guys decide becomes the standart. If you kill Net Neutrality might affect the whole world for the worst. Please, keep net neutrality.

In the face of everything we have seen, net neutrality is more essential now than ever. You may say that it is not your job to represent the public, but time and time again the public has made certain that you know that it wants net neutrality to be firmly protected by Title II regulations. \n\nThis is not optional, and anything else is blatantly anti-consumer, anti-internet, and anti-freedom. It is a shame to call the removal of these regulations, which ensure that all internet traffic is treated equally, regardless of political or technological content, a 'restoration of freedom'. Do what is right, and preserve net neutrality, protect consumers, and do your job. Any other outcome will ensure that you are viewed by history as someone who fought to hold back progress and justice in the name of greed.

Repealing even a small portion of net neutrality is a very big mistake. There is no justification to repealing these rules, or reclassifying internet service providers (ISP) as a title I instead of a title II. internet service providers have time and time again, proven they do not care about the consumer, and the majority of ISP's advocating to repeal net neutrality helps demonstrate this. ISP's only care about their bank account, and are willing to sacrifice any little thing, for a few extra bucks. \n\nI urge the representatives voting on this, to consider the consumer, not the ISP. Vote for the people who voted for you. Vote for their rights to privacy, and vote for their rights to equal speeds regardless to whatever internet resource they visit. Do not vote to weaken or remove net neutrality. The internet is a place for information, and learning. If the internet is allowed to be restricted by having net neutrality be removed, weakened, or not enforced. ISP's will then only favor those places that pay them. Do not trust the ISP's, as they have proven to be untrustworthy. Give the power back to the consumer. Vote to keep and strengthen net neutrality.

Net neutrality is absolutely essential for the internet to function and thrive. Removing it will allow corporations to destroy the freedom and open internet that has created so much good for the world.

If Mr. Pai of the FCC truly believes in a free and open market, he should NOT undo the work of Mr. Wheeler and destroy Net Neutrality. 

If Mr. Pai was truly working for the American people, he would not give Internet Service Providers the option to throttle content by adding "fast lanes" to the internet. This goes AGAINST the free market, letting companies choose who gets what service, as opposed to the consumer choosing the superior company. This is not the free market 'survival of the fittest,' this is artificial selection, with the companies choosing who wins and who loses.

When Net Neutrality was announced, the American people did not, contrary to what Mr. Pai had said, lost their freedom. They gained the ability to choose for themselves the kind of service they want.

Do not get rid of Net Neutrality. It is the will of the American people.

"Internet Freedom" for the carriers is not internet freedom for the people!  The internet and the broadband networks that carry it are such an integrated part of life - whether you're working, looking for work, accessing your medical records or just communicating with your friends and family - that it has become as important as electricity.  Maintaining Title II classification of Broadband providers, ensuring that they treat all data on the network equally, means that we, THE PEOPLE, don't get short-changed by providers looking for a competitive edge by throttling their competitors' data and boosting their own.  I expect to receive the same broadband speed whether I'm streaming through a Xbox, FireStick, Google or Verizon's proprietary device.  Every consumer, I believe, feels similarly.

President Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

Ending net neutrality will be bad for the average citizen, bad for America, and bad for the world.  Allowing a few massive companies to control the Internet in an oligopoly will simply increase their profits by extracting the wealth from everyone else, at the cost of more than just money, but freedom of expression and ideas.  The only people who stand to benefit are the shareholders of those companies and those they pay off, such as with the 11 million in lobbying money spent by AT&T, Verizon, and Comcast just in the first 3 months of 2017.  They spent that money to increase profits, not to increase access.  We've already seen with Comcast throttling bit torrent and other companies offering zero rating that ISPs will violate net neutrality if given the chance.  There's a reason why organizations whose goal is the preservation for the free Internet, like the EFF, are against ending net neutrality.  The Internet is more than just another product to be profited off of, it has been a critical utility in the lives of tens or hundreds of millions, with more every day.  \n\nMr. Pai, you already know all this.  You know ending net neutrality is wrong.  You know it is un-American to restrict freedom of information and expression.  The question is, why are you doing this, and how do you want to be remembered.  Do you want to go down in history as the person who laid the foundation for the destruction of mankind's greatest invention of the past 100 year?  Do what's right for the people you represent, and not the companies that stand to profit.

The government and the associated regulatory agencies of the government exist to benefit the human citizens (lawful citizens) that they serve. The laws and regulations enacted by the governing bodies of this country should not squelch the voice, welfare, and freedom of those whom they serve. Any proposed regulation, or proposed repeal of current regulations, that would allow soulless, non-citizen corporations to monetarily benefit at the expense of the lawful citizens should not be passed. Net Neutrality provides the lawful citizens of the United States of America one of the few avenues available to equally express their views and exercise their freedoms. Ending Net Neutrality would be a regressive move that further divides our country and would be a clear indication that the government, and the regulatory agencies of the government, value non-citizen corporations over the lawful citizens of the United States of America. Do not blemish the reputation of our country by dividing us through regressive regulation that carves deep chasms between lawful citizens, corporations, and governing bodies. We are supposed to be One Nation. Maintain Net Neutrality.

This proposal is insane. There is absolutely no reason internet providers, should be able to monitor traffic, benefit from selling usage information, or be able to give some traffic preferential treatment (e.g. Netflix has a deal with Comcast so they get priority over say, Youtube or a startup company.) \n\nISPs like Comcast already are basically monopolies. They already charge more than similar services in other countries. These put consumers in a position of having no choice and having no right to privacy.

I'm opposed to the current moves to de-regulate internet service providers by removing them from classification under Title II of the Federal Communications Act. ISPs have established a track record of looking for ways to make money at the expense of consumers. The internet is not a luxury -- it is essential in this day and age for people from all walks of life, both for work-related and private communications. For this reason, I strongly believe ISPs should be treated like utilities under Title II. It's not right that my internet history can be used by ISPs and sold without my bargained-for consent when I need to be online for school and work, or that certain internet traffic may be able to pay for special treatment, with potentially anti-competitive results.  If you de-regulate ISPs, they are sure to abuse this power. The Supreme Court affirmed the classification of ISPs under Title II. This should not be abandoned.

Obama’s Title II order must go.  It has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.  For these reasons, I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

The Title II ruling should remain. ISPs should be required to be impartial in data delivery.  Allowing manipulation of user requests puts power into the ISPs hands that they do not need.  Allowing a service providers to determine at their discretion what I am allowed to view, when I can view it, and at what speed is absurd. All data shall be treated equal!  The assumption that users even have a choice in a provider is unfounded.  In fact there have been cases of providers using their monopoly to prevent the construction of competing municipal ISPs.  It is crystal clear that we cannot trust ISPs to do what is in the best interest of its customers, only that of it's profits.  Keep ISPs as common carriers!

I absolutely want net neutrality to stay. The telecoms that run the infrastructure are also in many cases invested in media production and distribution (i.e. cable) and I don't FOR A MOMENT trust them not to degrade their online competitors. It's not even remotely a free market when an interested party is allowed to freely pick winners and losers, or extract rents from competitors in the form of traffic prioritization fees.

There's no universe in which eliminating net neutrality rules is anything but anti-competitive and something that will merely drive up costs for consumers and reinforce existing near-monopolies in the media space.

Keep net neutrality. Expand it, even.

DON'T KILL NET NEUTRALITY!!!!!\n\nISPs are Common Carriers - they are the gatekeepers to the public internet.

Any overturning  of Net Neutrality rules, as well as the overturning of Title II of ISPs would be an anti competitive move by the FCC.  It will only benefit ISPs (of all sizes) and do harm to their customers.  It will also allow the continuing 'double dipping' of the ISPs into customer's and Content provider's pockets.  This anti competitive move will only show that you in fact do not want competition for ISPs, only higher profits for them.  After you appointment with the FFC is over and you accept some position (as a lobbyist etc) it would only further provide evidence of collusion and corruption with the ISPs on their behalf.
Refer to Attachment(s).
Net Neutrality is VITAL to the future of Internet.  Please don't let the ISP's buy and/or lobby their way out of this requirement!!

Internet service providers should be regulated as common carriers and barred from prioritizing or providing content.  ISPs should be working for the customers who subscribe to internet service, not trying to take tolls or sell their own content which can lead to a conflict of interest.  ISPs should not be able to degrade a content provider in favor of their own, or bar access to a content provider.  Common Carrier provides the protections to the customers necessary.

Net neutrality and internet data privacy are two of the most critical topics of our era. Without an Internet whose freedom is protected via strong net neutrality regulations preventing the prioritization of certain data over others, it is inevitable that carriers will create "Walled Gardens" similar to the old, dead AOL model, which the market killed, and which the monopolistic nature of end user access facilitates the re-creation of. A strong, neutral Internet makes for a strong, free America; de-regulating net neutrality and "trusting" the providers to "do the right thing" will result in a weaker, less free America bound by strictures imposed to increase profitability, not to accommodate free exchange of ideas. 

It is even more critical that Americans re-gain the right to control the dissemination of their data, including metadata generated and retained by carriers and third parties on the Internet. Browsing habits and internet usage can provide a deep look into a person's personal life, exposing as much or more about them as browsing through their bedroom nightstand or desk drawers might. Allowing this data to be aggregated and sold will mean the literal death of privacy on the internet, as companies compete to gather even more information about the subscriber to sell to third parties. This is intrusive, and abusive, and is a behavior that the FCC has been right to prevent in the past. 

Please do the right thing and rule on behalf of the consumers, not the corporations. They already have almost all of the power- please do not cede the small foothold that The People have remaining to corporate interests.

I do not support this proposal.  Having a neutral internet enshrined in federal law is the only way to stop the abusive ISPs we have in this country from destroying the internet.  Every other developed country has enshrined strong net neutrality laws, even Canada passed even strong laws just a few weeks ago.  The united states should lead here, not give into industry demands at the expense of consumers.  Please do your job and protect consumers, don't give these huge monopoly companies an even bigger hand out, they don't need it.

Hello my name is Carmine from Key West Florida and I find Chairman Pai's plan to kill net neutrality terrible for the American public at large. On open Internet builds innovation and enables the free market to decide what is best for itself. Facebook is alive today because of Net Neutrality. Without it MySpace would have been able to pay higher premium and if Facebook couldn't compete it would have been all over for a once tiny company. I don't have a company but if I come up with a billion dollar idea or an innovation that could save lives in couldn't tell the world. America suffers from the top to the bottom of the economic ladder without net Neutrality. This isn't good for anyone but the ISP's and even for them they don't need this. They aren't suffering as they have pseudo monopolies that ensure costumers. \n\nThank you -Carmine

I am AGAINST the push to remove net neutrality laws. Keeping the internet neutral has propelled the american economy to new heights in the last few decades. By stripping net neutrality laws we will be handing over control of the internet to the already entrenched companies, preventing new entities from ever joining the market. Once we do this companies will leave America to find internet ecosystems that are more fair and accessible to them. The high-tech economy that America has so enjoyed will quickly go away, costing us countless jobs across countless sectors. These rules will not just effect the silicon valley technical jobs, but will reach into every single company in the country.\n\nNet neutrality must stay, for the sake of American jobs, the American economy, and for the sake of fairness.

How is throttling bad for consumers? Let me put it into terms an infant could understand. \n\nYou get your water from a hose. There is enough water for you and all of your neighbors to get water from this hose. The provider of the water decides to limit you on how much water you are allowed to get over a set amount of time. You pay for the water, so you should be able to get all the water you pay for, but some idiot in the FCC decided that they can limit your water to what they consider to be the amount you should get and how fast you should get it. Because of this you don't have enough water to bathe when you want, drink when you want, or cook with when you want.

Please uphold the Title II and net neutrality for internet traffic, Broadband internet is an extremely noncompetitive market place with most areas having only one provider who holds a monopoly, some of which have legally blocked anyone from being able to compete by blocking utility pole access or other exclusivity deals.  Paid Prioritization would stifle innovation, growth, and hinder american small businesses from creating jobs, by allowing the provider to slow to the point of unsuitability any third party competing service. This is by definition protectionism and it should be legally prevented. 

Billing should also be transparent all providers regardless of size should disclose and hidden fees or data caps, either for throttling  or blocking purposes.

Providers must remain as common carriers under Title II of the Communications Act, anything less would be Un-American

Network neutrality rules are essential for continued innovation on the free internet. Look at streaming companies like Netflix. They use tons of data and effectively are what most internet users consider the backbone of media consumption in the US. To make a Netflix, you just need a server and some bandwidth. Network neutrality guarantees that this bandwidth gets the same access privileges as big companies like Netflix. Don't kill innovation: keep network neutrality so that new, innovative companies can step forward and build competitors to Netflix. That is, don't let companies extort money in order to deliver the "same performance" as big companies -- and don't let prioritization be a monetary thing.\n\nMr. Ajit Pai, you are in charge of the FCC to serve the country. Serve your country, not companies that lobby and people who have a vested stake in ensuring that the internet doesn't innovate. Network neutrality is a fundamental, important facet that must be maintained.

Mr Ajit Pai,

Please let me be fundamentally clear, your apparent belief that Net Neutrality has no purpose in the world today, let me clarify its purpose for you.  It is there to protect consumers who have PAID for access to whatever they want, provided its legal and NO ONE, not the ISP nor The Web Site or Service Provider may take efforts to influence or mitigate any access to any or all sites on the INTERNET, basically, we as end users pay for a pipe, nothing more.  Your predecessor understood this but apparently you are too lost in your love for ISP's to understand this.  You ask why ISP's should be treated like phone companies using old laws? ? It makes more sense than you think, how about we explain it like this, if I told you that only calls to  your immediate relatives would be clear and static free, unless of course your friends decided to pay "extra" to have that same service be allowed to your line.  Both you and your friends pay for telephone services, why would the phone company be allowed to choose who you get to call clearly, I call BS, they don't, and neither should the ISP's decide what sites I get to visit and who gets to  pay more money to guarantee "better access" to their own site.  Net Neutrality guarantees that traffic is traffic, no games, no taking our money and manipulating our choices through gaming the system, Please admit you are a shill for the ISP's
Please resign and put an actual human being back in the Chairman's Chair, robots are good as maids, and to vacuum our carpets, but not good to make serious and critical choices for us.  Please Mr Robot Pai, walk away for the good of all of us and let the Actual experts make better choices for us all.

You, the FCC and it's chairman, have already given away access to the internet to a mere handful of providers because of your allegiance that leans more to the Communication companies you are supposed to regulate than the American people. In my municipality, I have two options for high speed internet...think about that. TWO!  This is competition?? Now this legislation??  This is your final death blow that allows the oligarchy of ISPs to control not only access to the internet but the internet itself. This legislation is disgusting and an appalling exercise in corporate control of our government. I used to be employed for 10+ years by who is now the 2nd largest ISP in the United States and I know their tactics all too well but it seems the already have the FCC it's in clutches because of their bought stooge is now chairman of the agency meant to regulate it. This is a TOTAL failure of government, you should be ashamed but you wont be because your corporate masters make sure to shield you from it.

Net neutrality was already in place and working very well prior to FCC Chairman Pai's promotion. I don't see how how this proposal is helpful to American citizens using the internet. If this proposal goes through, I'll be less free in terms of what I can do on the internet. Only internet service providers stand to benefit (financially) from this proposal.

Please do not eliminate net neutrality. Without it, companies will be able to unfairly limit competition, more easily establish monopolies, and generally destroy the concept of a free and open Internet.

The FCC's purpose is to provide consumer protection while regulating the communications industry to allow a viable means to provide those communications services.  This proposal to remove Title II "net neutrality" rules is precisely the equivalent of returning the telephone industry back to one company - a no choice, anti-consumer, entirely one-sided, pro-monopolistic stance from the entity in government that exists, in part, to PREVENT monopolistic behaviors.  This proposal flies in the face of consumer choice, consumer benefit and consumer interests SO MUCH, it begs the question of exactly what was the current FCC chairman paid, or promised, by the ISP's to so consistently advocate against consumers and in their favor?  Our government is of the people, by the people, and for the people.  This proposal is not.  It's that simple.

At my day job, I work on a massively multiplayer online game. At home, I keep in contact with my friends and family through a variety of applications and services. In my relationship with my girlfriend, because we're long-distance, a fast and reliable means of communication is vital.

All of these things rely on a neutral, regulated internet, where ISPs have no say in what goes over their lines.

Please: Keep Net Neutrality alive. We wanted it before, and we still want it now. My livelihood, my social circle, and my love life - essentially, everything I am - relies on it.

I live 30 minutes outside Boston.  I have one ISP provider that offers speeds greater than 2 mbs download speeds.  I have never lived in a place with the option of more than one ISP that provided anything approaching broadband speeds and I have never lived more than an hour outside of Boston, a major metropolitan area.  Approximately 1/3 of the country also has only one ISP option.  Please explain how this classifies as competition.  What would you say if 1/3 of the country was forced to buy a Ford and the other 2/3 were forced to buy a Ford or a GM?  In no other industry would this be accepted as being competitive, so why exactly are rules being removed on the basis that "the market place is competitive".\n\nPlease base decisions on actual facts and not all the money the ISP must be paying you, because there is no other explanation.  Maybe it's just because I'm a network engineer so I actually know how the internet functions and it's not how you think it is...
Refer to Attachment(s).

I am unequivocally opposed to the proposed plan to rescind the title II classification for ISPs.   Content-neutral internet access has become an essential service bordering on a human right.  To propose that regulation enforcing content-neutrality is unnecessary in a market prone to natural monopolies is both absurd and immoral.

I work as an engineering manager at a small video streaming video start up, and the last thing we need is to pay additional tolls in order to get our content to our users. Reversing net neutrality rules would put our company at a disadvantage when competing against entrenched companies like Amazon or Netflix, let alone competing against the companies that sell internet access to our end users, like Comcast, Time Warner, or Verizon.\n\nIn order to have a vibrant, free, and innovative internet, I urge you preserve and expand the existing regulations that protect small business against rent seeking and unfair competition.

As it currently stands today, consumers have the freedom to go to any website they wish with the same speed and ability to access said website as any other. Ending net neutrality via the "Restore Internet Freedom" act, letting ISPs vary and/or remove the ability to access certain websites is nothing more than restrictions designed to let ISPs make more money off individuals and businesses alike. Millions of people and businesses alike have millions of different internet needs and suddenly putting the internet into cable-like packages and the like will not help address those needs. Ending Net Neutrality and Title II only helps line the ISPs pockets.  If you truly care about the freedoms of the American people and businesses you will leave the Net Neutrality and Title II alone.

I believe that true net neutrality is important for providing information equally across socioeconomic levels.  The protections that are in place provide a measure of safety for consumers, including schools and students in low income areas. Weakening or removing the current protections or changing the way they are enforced will be detrimental to the free flow of information. I will support a new regulations only if they guarantee the same or better protections. I do not support  repealing  Title II.

If you look at the state of internet access in the US compared to other developed countries in Europe and the East, it's awful  (reference http://www.pbs.org/newshour/updates/internet-u-s-compare-globally-hint-slower-expensive/).  If you look at telecommunication regulations in the US compared to other developed countries in Europe and the East, they're generally looser.  Do some science; we have more than one data point in the world.

The profit margins for large internet service providers are already sky-high (reference http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bruce-kushnick/time-warner-cables-97-pro_b_6591916.html)  In most places they're effectively monopolies, and they remain so via uncompetitive practices like suing start-up competitors and keeping them tied up in court over nothing until they go out of business.  The business doesn't need help, the consumer needs help.  Treating and regulating internet like a utility, as it has been in multiple municipalities throughout the country, tends to get you extremely fast and extremely cheap internet.

Regards,
Simon Heath

Thank you for making this process transparent as promised Chairman Pai. That being said, this proposal is terrible. First its title is clearly meant to manipulate Americans into believing its for the good of them, when it will strip them of liberties much like The Patriot Act. A deceptive thing to do. Second, the only freedoms being granted are to multi-billion dollar telecom companies who clearly don't need them but also at the expense of the consumer. We already went down this road for a decade searching in vain for good net neutrality rules outside of Title 2, why do you want more of that? Why do you want to destroy something that clearly works and is rightly approved of the vast majority of internet users? This will make the wealth gap even greater by allowing ISPs to charge more for popular sites. If the industry was full of companies competing for customers and not the huge monopolistic industry dominated by Comcast and Spectrum that we have, this proposal would be ok. But it isn't. Those companies will charge what they want(more) for what we'll get(less) and we'll be forced to do so if this proposal comes to pass.
I disagree with Chairman Pai.  Net Neutrality must be preserved.

I write to share three thoughts and concerns with the FCC's NPRM. 

First, the NPRM makes a number of comments discussing the "dynamic broadband Internet access service marketplace" (¶ 33) and the "unprecedented growth" of Internet services. I agree that the internet has undergone a rapid shift in the last two decades as it went from being a niche service to an omnipresent aspect of modern life for consumers.  However, the NPRM fails to note that much of the innovation and services that consumers think about relate to companies offering services and websites that interact WITH the internet and basic internet infrastructure, not with respect to the actual network providers who transport data from one place to another. Put another way, each day in Silicon Valley (where I work in live), there is another group of would-be startup founders looking to be the next Facebook. No one is clamoring to be the next Comcast.

Second, I fundamentally disagree with the NPRM's approach to the classification between providers of "telecommunications" and "information services."  Providers of internet access do in fact transmit information of the user's choosing, contrary to Paragraph 29 of the NPRM.  When I tell my browser to load Twitter, a connection is made between myself (a point of my choosing) and Twitter's servers (a point which I have chosen to access). The suggestion that every internet user need understand the DNS system before such a request would qualify as a "telecommunications" service misses the point: the average use of a landline phone (or more realistically a smartphone) does not know how the handset translates the sound waves of their voice into an analog (or digital) signal, nor do they know how the phone company figures out the path between the caller and the person they intend to contact. They do, however, expect that the sound of their voice will (largely) be transferred as they perceive it, and vice versa with the person on the other end. With respect to the question proposed in Paragraph 29, the "ambiguous" words should be given their plain and commonly understood meaning: the user defines the endpoints of the communication. Telecommunications services transmit messages between parties who wish to communicate, whether that is my mother calling me on a phone, or whether that is my best friend sending me an instant message using Whatsapp.

The fact that internet service providers engage in network management (such as using firewalls to block malicious attacks, or managing the move from IPv4 to IPv6 IP addresses) (¶ 30) does not mean that ISPs provide "information" to consumers.  Network management is necessary to ensure that the intended communications between consumers can be reasonably transferred.  Yes, it is true that internet users expect that their ISP will be able to handle backend issues (such as IP address translation) in order to enable access to an online service, but so too do users of telecommunications equipment expect their telecommunications provider to ensure their infrastructure is robust enough to transmit requests, whether that be fixing downed telephone lines or ensuring that "phreakers" can't abuse the network to the detriment of other users. 

Third, the NPRM (and the public comments surrounding the process leading up to the NPRM) seems oblivious as to the realities of broadband deployment for most consumers and how broadband access differs from access to popular online services. Online services may be gated by age, but many permit consumers to sign up for free and generate revenue from advertising. Others charge recurring or one-time fees to access their services, but permit any consumer willing to pay the fee to sign up.  By contrast, broadband providers only service discrete, physical areas, and availability is determined by physical location rather than interest in the service. An unhappy Uber user deletes the app and moves to Lyft; an unhappy Comcast user must move homes for better broadband. The latter situation is far more similar to telecom providers than providers of information.

A few months ago, I renewed the lease at my apartment and needed to renew my internet service. My building is wired so that the only broadband provider is Comcast -- they are the only way I can use the internet at speeds higher than 10 Mb/s.  When I called to renew, I knew their website would let me sign up for internet at $40/month at comparable speeds to my plan. However, their retention department refused to budge, insisting that I pay significantly more and that it was the "best price" they could do. And I realized at that moment, there was nothing I could do. I could have tried a DSL provider, paying similar amounts of money for slower speeds. I could try using my phone to tether, before my mobile provider realized and tried to cut me off. But ultimately, because broadband deployment in this country has resulted in most homes only having a single option for anything close to high speeds, I had no ability to watch news online, access email from friends, family, and elected representatives, or work online as required for my job without giving in to the price that was demanded of me.  Consumers have absolutely zero leverage or bargaining power when it comes to broadband providers, despite a robust competition in online services that require internet access to use.

The NPRM is titled "Restoring Internet Freedom," ostensibly out of a concern the current internet is not "free."  If the Federal Communications Commission seeks to ensure reasonable internet access for a modern America, it ignores at its peril that few Americans are "free" to choose their internet provider.  In an age where internet providers are increasingly consolidating each other, this is the wrong time to leave them to their own devices.

The Federal Communication Commission's website states one of its strategic goals is "protection public interest goals."  The proposed "Light-Touch" regulatory framework does not further that purpose.

Net neutrality is a positive for all Americans. That all data is treated equally and fairly by telecom providers is a crucial tool for ensuring freedom of speech and free and fair discourse. Freedom of speech is not a right any American company should be allowed to choose who "complies" with. Thank you for your time and consideration.

Dear FCC, \nI am writing you today to voice my opinion that net neutrality must be upheld as much as possible. If the current measures under consideration go through, it will do nothing to help people like me and other citizens who use the internet for their work. High-speed internet is also one of the most widely available and accessible outlets for reaching an audience, and if the government puts citizens entirely at the mercy of ISPs for their access to high-speed internet, it will have failed them; the ability of people to use the internet to enrich themselves and perform public speech is, in the current era, important to their personal freedom, and it is your duty to protect that. If the FCC is to do its duty to the American people, it must oppose the Restoring Internet Freedom proceeding.

Please KEEP current net neutrality rules!!! ISP's should NOT be allowed to charge sites or apps for network performance, as it'll decrease creativity and strangle companies like mine. ISP's should NOT be allowed to charge different prices for preferential treatment. KEEP Title 2 rules in place, keeping ISP's as common carriers like the phone companies. To not do so would be a disaster for the internet ecosystem.

As a professional designer of websites, mobile apps and web-based software, I strongly oppose recategorization of the Internet so that it is no longer considered a standard public service utility. The internet is vital and essential. Companies should not be allowed to create premium-access levels that only benefit their own bottom line. Throttling should definitely be regulated. Past ISP actions have required court intervention. Net neutrality laws are NECESSARY consumer protection for every internet user. Eliminating net neutrality strikes me as being anti-business and anti-capitalist, and not at all healthy for new product innovation.

Internet should be regulated like phone lines.  Companies should not be allowed to prioritize traffic in ways that limit any one network traffic type when compared to another. Municipal broadband should be a viable option and not be restricted or prohibited.   Incentives should exist to improve network speeds to consumers.

I use my internet service primarily as a communication device.  I do not want my ISP  trying to determine if my communications are legal. I do not want my ISP monitoring my online activities at all. I really have little choice as to the internet service I use. . In San Diego, the sixth largest city in the nation there are only 2 providers of internet service.  Internet providers act like utilities in that they do not compete with each other. They break the nation into segments and refuse to enter each others territory.  They need close scrutiny to keep Americans speech to each other free.  Free from intrusion, free from monitoring of any sort including advertising opportunities.  The technology used for this can easily be used for  political repression as well. I do not want my ISP throttling my service if I don't use their approved (zero-rated) services

This is a blatant corporate sell out, and will strongly hamper the economic and intellectual growth of the nation in favor of  lining the pockets of the major telecoms.\n\nThis will have long lasting and incredibly damaging consequences.

Please keep net neutrality as a core concept in the expansion of the internet.  Bits are bits.  Giving priority to one service over another on the internet is like having a different cost for water that you drink compared to water that you use to wash your hands.

The internet is required for modern life. Recently I graduated college and obtained a new job. Job applications were done completely online. Internet should be treated like a telephone where it is a means to communicate and participate in modern life. Rules are needed to keep ISP's to ensure these companies can't manipulate traffic and create a pay to win scenario. A private company should not have the power to manipulate website  connection speed and control what people can see. The internet is a utility just like power and a phone. Title II has successfully done this for telephones and should continue for the internet and ISP's.

Overturning net neutrality makes incumbent ISPs the de facto gatekeepers of the internet. Given that there is little to no competition within the ISP market this means that subscribers will be beholden to the whims of their ISPs when seeking content. Even if there were real competition in the ISP market it would still make ISPs the gatekeepers of content. This is completely unacceptable. Subscribers pay for access to the internet. All of it. KEEP NET NEUTRALITY.

I support full net neutrality and the classification of ISPs as common carriers under Title II of the Communications Act. Removing these rules will be harmful to consumers. \n\nIn addition, I support the transparency rule requiring ISPs to more clearly disclose hidden fees and data caps. This additional information improves competition between ISPs and enables consumers to make better buying decisions.

Please reconsider enacting the "Restoring Internet Freedom" act. Even with the implementation of Net Neutrality legislation and the determination that internet service fell under Title II classification, service providers have already begun down a slippery slope of zero-rating content, playing favorites, stifling competition, and attempting to create 'walled gardens' of tiered content; all of these activities are at direct odds with the idea of a free internet.

The notion that any regulation is _Bad_, and that a lack of regulation is, therefore, inherently _Good_ does not bear out in this situation. It is akin to stating that the first amendment is a top-down power grab in an attempt to legislate what does and does not constitute 'free speech' and that we should therefore enact a "Restoring Speech Freedom" bill, which would repeal the first amendment because speech would better flourish under a 'light-touch approach.' This is a hyperbolic analogy, of course, but I feel the comparison is apt (if somewhat heavy-handed).

Consider cell phone providers (an increasingly important player in the ever-changing landscape of the internet) who do not count data used in the consumption of certain services (Spotify/Netflix/Pandora/etc) against data utilization limits, and the effect this seemingly-beneficial and apparently-benevolent action has. Competitors to the zero-rated services now face the inherent hurdle to reaching a customer base posed by the fact that their potential users would be disadvantaged by the use of their data. This represents a decreasingly level playing field, and this type of behavior has only just begun; since it was enacted by one provider, others have rapidly begun their adoption of similar practices. As a growing number of service providers implement and expand this type of data classification and throttling, it will only get worse. Established companies (Amazon, Facebook, Google, etc.) will be able to afford to pay for such benefits, but 'garage' tech startups will be unable to do so; in this type of environment, the very same technological behemoths who now stand to benefit would never have come to power. The very heart of technological disruptions and the core concept of technological competition, growth, and development are fundamentally reliant upon the notion that a good idea, implemented well, can compete with and disrupt an industry, because all traffic is treated equally. If ISPs had provided fast lanes for Altavista, while throttling Google, or if providers counted data used at Facebook against a user's data cap, while zero-rating MySpace, it would not have mattered who had the superior product, because the public would never have been exposed to the fledgling start-ups; this is not competition. Neither end users nor software developers should have limits imposed upon them (either directly, via throttling; or indirectly, via the advantages provided to competing data); THIS constitutes the core of internet freedom, not some pedantic discussion regarding the definition of terms or services. However, if we would prefer to be pedantic, please consider the practice of the widespread abuse of the word "unlimited" by service providers. Throttling or capping data beyond a certain threshold of consumption constitutes a limit, plain and simple. This blatant disregard for what is in the best interest of the consumer is possible because all providers do the same thing, precluding any notion that market forces will sway them to stop, and the high cost of entrance into the marketplace prevents any disruption by new competition. Additionally, consider the limited range of offerings available to the majority of your constituency. In almost all areas of the nation, consumers' decisions regarding internet service is heavily restricted. People living in multi-tenant properties typically have the choice to use the provider who services that complex, or move to another one (which, for many, many people, constitutes an untenable financial burden). People in rural areas (which constitute a geographical majority of the nation) often face similar situations, wherein they have the options of dial-up, excessively expensive (and still slow/unreliable) satellite, or nothing at all. Even those living in major metropolitan areas are limited to the very few options in their area, with perhaps two or three providers at most.

With diminishing choices available to consumers, providers will have increasing freedom to do whatever they please, which likely equates to whatever best suits their bottom line. This is the nature of business, and is not inherently bad, but it _does_ necessitate consumer protection, and the only even-handed method for implementing such protection is at the federal level. The tools to do this are already in place; we only need them to be enforced. This is not the smothering over-regulation of a draconian, legislation-happy, nanny state; this is one of the fundamental arguments _for the existence of a government in the first place_. If a government does not protect the rights of its citizens and provide the infrastructure of freedom, then what _does_ it do? Access to a free (as in speech) and open internet, where the only cost of admission is the metaphorical cover charge to get in the door, is rapidly becoming a necessary part of American life. The American Dream of pulling oneself up by the bootstraps, overcoming their circumstances, and building a better life (not only for themselves, but for all who come behind them) is still alive. It manifests in every child who learns the valuable tech skills (that, too often, their school cannot understand or afford) online, in every low-wage employee taking online courses so that they can move from a job into a career, and every factory worker who sees that their industry is changing, and goes online to learn what they can do to move with it. If none of those examples appeal to you, then, Mr. Pai, please consider the effect of the internet on the trajectory of a man who rose from being a name in real estate and reality television to the candidate that so many institutions said would never win, who defied those odds, and has recently placed you in your position. 

If you truly care about internet freedom, as the nomenclature of your legislation would imply, and are not simply using the title as a blatantly manipulative play to knee-jerk flag-waving sentimentality, I ask that you not only cease any attempt at passing this legislation, but that you reverse course, and instead seek to enforce the regulations commonly referred to under the name of Net Neutrality.

I sincerely thank you for your time in reading this, regardless of whether or not you take any of it to heart (although, of course, I hope you do).

Hi, my name is Artem Slivka from Westfield , MA . I'd like to register my opinion in support of Net Neutrality. Chairman Pai's recent decision to move toward a non-Net-Neutrality position of the FCC is a poor decision for the American people and will result in higher rates, lower competition, and a severe lack of innovation due to content providers having all the power.

I urge you in the strongest possible terms to protect the Internet by preserving the strong net neutrality rules implemented by former chairman Wheeler. As you know, throttling and blocking has already grievously harmed consumers, and that will only be exacerbated by your threatened removal of net neutrality protections. Please do not allow these radical changes to the fundamental structure of the Internet that has served us so well for decades.

Obama’s Title II order has diminished broadband investment, stifled innovation, and left American consumers potentially on the hook for a new broadband tax.

These regulations ended a decades-long bipartisan consensus that the Internet should be regulated through a light touch framework that worked better than anyone could have imagined and made the Internet what it is.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Paragraph 82 asks for feedback on whether throttling should be regulated. In the past ISPs have throttled content. It is mostly based on their own determination of what was lawful or permissible, and had to be forced to stop in the courts. Is it not possible they could do the same thing again? I’m also concerned by mobile providers who say a plan is “unlimited,” but when you exceed the data cap, only throttle sites and services that aren’t part of their approved zero-rating network. This gives priority to those business large enough to pay for zero-rating, completely going against the ideology of a free and open internet.

Thank you.
Chris

Re: Promoting consumer choice via market principles.

A requirement of a free market is an informed consumer. To address the proposal's goal of allowing for consumer choice and freedom to innovate by internet service providers, I propose the following rule:

1) When a customer signs up with an ISP, the ISP must prominently state their net neutrality policy, in a format to be determined by the commission.
2) An ISP is prohibited from modifying their net neutrality policy for the duration of that customer's contiguous service, except by explicit consent of the customer.

Traffic management policies of ISPs are normally invisible to consumers, and subject to change by the ISP at any time. In order for consumers to make an informed decision, visibility and stability of those traffic management policies is required. This does not impose any restrictions on ISPs nor on consumers. It just ensures consumers can make informed decisions.

I work for Comcast. I work from home, using the Internet to do my job. To make the money that keeps me from being homeless, allows me to eat and live. Even india and Canada have decided to uphold their laws, against all odds,

How many times does the average American have to be screwed for every penny they have in the name of maximizing corporate profit?  Where do you think all those dollars go?  Back to the people?
