Stripping net neutrality would take an existing problem with internet regulations and make it many times worse.  Regulations and protections should only be removed when the benefits for society are explicitly laid out and understood.  Internet Service Providers already have a monopoly on broadband internet in many municipalities across the US.  This is already a major problem, as it gives them the ability to arbitrarily hike up prices with no possible recourse from the customer (there are no competitors to turn to).  Contrary to chairman Pai's absurd claims that the internet is not a necessity, the internet is in fact vital to any American who wants to maintain a professional life in this country.  The only way to continue to progress as a nation is to reclassify broadband internet as a utility and impose *more* regulations to restrict price hiking.  

One argument I've seen to support stripping net neutrality is that it allows ISPs to make more money which can be invested in the development of improved hardware, and ultimately faster, cheaper internet.  This is, of course, a very flimsy argument - to illustrate, imagine that you are Time Warner Cable or Comcast.  You make revenue off of internet and cable subscriptions, and have very little overhead expenses beyond the initial installment of cable networks.  You have no competitors in most cities, and customers will subscribe to your internet plan no matter what.  You are currently losing many cable customers to new and innovative entertainment platforms such as Netflix or Hulu that are not horrendously overpriced because they actually have to compete with each other everywhere.  In this case, you are not motivated to provide high-speed internet, because it simply enables customers to use these new services as an alternative to your overpriced cable TV subscription.  Why would you invest money into providing your customers with a better, faster, cheaper product?  They would simply use that faster internet connection to stream entertainment which is determined by fair market prices instead of subscribing to your monopolistic cable TV subscription.  Worse - what is to stop you from increasing the price by 600% on a whim?  Or providing abysmal customer service?  What are customers going to do?  Go to a competitor?  They don't exist.  

Now, to complicate things, let's also remove all net neutrality regulations as well.  Now you have the ability to arbitrarily decide that Netflix and Hulu must pay you much more per requested bit of data.  This forces them to increase the prices for THEIR customers, and in the end, it essentially allows you to indirectly *punish* customers for attempting to bypass your unfairly priced products which face no market competition.

In this case, entertainment is only one small aspect of how innovation in business is damaged.  In other industries that are web-based, large, well-established companies can organize exclusive deals with the ISPs, making it nearly impossible for any small companies looking to enter the market to compete.  Reduction of regulations is not inherently bad, but it must be done with the intention of *increasing* competition and innovation.  This is the spirit which drives America forward, and it is the abandonment of this spirit which has saddled the American people with substandard, overpriced internet service.  Companies need to be rewarded for contributing *more* to society, not punished for making the big dogs look bad.  Why would we give incentive to anyone to provide a more expensive, slower internet and willingly remove all competitive threats?  This action by Chairman Pai cannot stand.  This is shameless corruption and the American people won't stand by and allow you to trample our basic rights.

Hello! An open and free internet is critical to not only freedom of speech but our modern economy as well. I am a startup founder and the only way I can operate is if the ISPs treat all customers equally whether going to a website or serving a website. We DO need a rule AGAINST blocking, throttling and paid prioritization because that is what protects my freedom of speech. I understand the complicated nature of it all but these are not cable TV channels and the web is what it is because of the freedom it facilitates. The internet is required for finding a job and in many cases paying bills and simply communicating, it is a utility in every sense of the word, it should not be regulated in favor of ISPs looking for more profit. Thank you for considering my point of view.

In the early days, the Internet operated successfully without title II classification or net neutrality regulations for ISPs. However, as ISPs consolidated, most local markets became single-provider (in fact or in practice), ISPs realized the profit potential from new tech and a captive customer base, and innovations created services that directly competed with the ISPs' new owners' core businesses (VOIP for DSL providers like AT&T, Netflix and other video-on-demand services for cable companies like Comcast). ISPs now had reason to interfere with Internet traffic to their customers, the means to do so, and no regulations prohibiting this.

And in fact they did interfere. Comcast blocked or degraded P2P traffic. AT&T forced Apple to block VOIP services including Skype from iPhones that used its service, and later tried to block Facetime. AT&T, Sprint and Verizon all blocked Google Wallet in favor of their own mobile payment platform, Isis (yep). MetroPCS tried to block all streaming services except YouTube. And many smaller ISPs started hijacking their customers' search engine inquiries to redirect them to search engines that the ISPs received financial compensation from.

Following the eventual imposition of Title II common-carrier requirements, these innovation-killing, choice-killing impositions from the ISPs stopped, to the great benefit of everyone. Note that the second web economy boom followed Title II classification.

The Internet is an open, lightly regulated and very successful commons that is of great benefit to people and businesses all over the globe. However, ISPs are *not* the Internet, they're the gatekeepers to getting on the Internet. Please continue Title II classification and the imposition of common-carrier rules on ISPs. Doing so will keep the Internet as it is today - a free, open and fair place for ideas to compete.  Thank you!

I fully expect this comment to be ignored.  I believe the committee has already made their decision and is soliciting comments solely to fulfill a requirement.  

I am unclear how allowing broadband companies to charge their customers for preferential access to their destinations, alongside charging other companies for preferential access to their customers will spur innovation or competition.  Especially as the large providers that the vast majority of  Americans use, straddle both sides as both an internet and content provider.  Allowing them to prioritize their own content while deprioritizing the competition, which seems to allow them to abuse their role of ISP to hinder competition in the content market.  At best, it allows them to extract tolls on both ends for the use of their "roads" that their own traffic can be exempted from.  

If there were true competition in the broadband market, this would not be an issue, but over 90% of Americans are faced with either effective monopoly or duopoly situations.  Additionally, this lack of true competition eliminates price competition between companies.  If I am unhappy with Comcast's service or prices, I can call and complain, but my other options are either ISPs that are leasing space from Comcast, and will be subject to the same issues, or CenturyLink which offers worse reliability.  If ISPs were forcibly decoupled from their content producing arms, and solely sold access to their network, this would be a fine solution.  But that's not the case.

The subject notice seeks comment on the analysis provided. The following comments are hereby submitted.
Paragraph 27 purports to show that broadband Internet service is an information service because it provides users the "capability for generating, acquiring, storing, transforming, processing, retrieving, utilizing, or making available information via telecommunications." The argument given is that broadband Internet service allows users to do all these things. However, this is not the same as providing the capability to do these things. To see why, consider that providing users Internet services over dialup phone lines also allows users to do all these things; but the phone lines themselves are telecommunications services, not information services. Why? Because providing the user dialup Internet, by itself, does not provide them the capability to do all these things. That capability is provided by the endpoints: the users' computers, and the computers hosting the Internet services that the users connect to.
Exactly the same is true of broadband Internet services provided by ISPs: by themselves, they do not provide users the capability to do all these things. They only provide connections between computers at the endpoints that provide those capabilities. It is the services provided by the Internet hosts that users connect to that are "information services". The broadband Internet services that allow users to connect to those hosts are telecommunications services, and should be regulated as such.
ISPs object to analyses like the one above because they claim that they also provide the actual information services--in other words, they also provide Internet hosts that function as email servers, web servers, etc. But it is obvious that those services are separate from the broadband connection services provided by those same ISPs, because users can make use of the latter without making use of the former at all. I am such a user: I use the broadband Internet connection provided by my ISP, but I do not use any of the information services they provide; I do not use their email, their web hosting, etc. I use other Internet hosts provided by other companies for those services. The fact that ISPs offer information services as well as telecommunications services does not make their telecommunications services into information services; an ISP's choice of business model cannot change the nature of a particular service it provides. Broadband Internet connections are obviously a telecommunications service, and should be regulated as such, regardless of what other services ISPs would like to bundle with them.
Paragraph 28 asks whether "offering Internet access is precisely what makes the service capable of 'generating, acquiring, storing, transforming, processing, retrieving, utilizing, or making available information' to consumers?" The answer to this question, as noted above, is no, because all of those capabilities are not provided by the mere fact of Internet access; they are provided by the endpoint computers that implement those capabilities. The question of how those computers are connected to each other, which is the relevant question for the purpose of determining whether broadband Internet service is a telecommunications service, is a separate question from the question of what capabilities the endpoint computers provide.
Paragraph 28 also asks whether consumers could "access these online services using traditional telecommunications services like telephone service or point-to-point special access?" Obviously the answer to this question will depend on what connectivity the providers of such telecommunications services choose to provide. But that is a different question from the question of what the nature of a particular service is. Again, the question of how computers are connected to each other is separate from the question of what capabilities the endpoint computers provide.
Paragraph 29 attempts to argue, in effect, that if most Internet users rely on their ISPs for any additional service beyond the bare fact of Internet connectivity--for example, DNS--then broadband Internet service must be an information service. Paragraph 29 also claims that the ISP, not the user, "specifies the points between and among which information will be transmitted", because, first, users only specify domain names, not IP addresses, and second, users do not make the routing decisions that determine the specific path information packets take through the network. Neither of these considerations affects the proper classification of broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service. Users might only specify domain names, but the service of translating domain names into IP addresses is provided by an endpoint--a DNS server--not by the bare provision of an Internet connection. (And even if the ISP typically provides this endpoint, that is still a separate service from the service of providing an Internet connection, and, as above, bundling the two together cannot change the nature of the latter.) Once the DNS service has provided an IP address corresponding to a domain name to the user's computer, the user's computer, not the network, specifies that IP address as the target of information packets, so once again, it is an endpoint, not the network itself, that determines where the information goes. And routing information packets, in and of itself, is not an information service, because it does not change the information being routed; it just accomplishes the information transmission specified by the user, from one endpoint to another. The intermediate routers that pass on information packets are not endpoints: they are not specified by the user as the targets of any information, and they do not provide any of the capabilities that make an endpoint a provider of an information service.
The analysis of Paragraph 29 also fails to take into account that, if it were valid, it would apply equally well to traditional phone service, which is admitted to be a telecommunications service. Users specify phone numbers to dial, but that does not require knowledge of the physical location of the target phone (and the user will often not have such knowledge), nor does it specify the route that will be taken by the information transmitted by the call. Also, traditional phone service includes directory service (411) and other "add-ons" that go beyond the basic provision of a connection. What makes those "add-ons" telecommunications services rather than information services is that they are for the purpose of facilitating the connection (or facilitating the refusal of connections which are not desired), rather than acting on the information exchanged between the users at the endpoints.
Paragraph 30 attempts to argue that network management activities such as firewalling and IPV4 - IPV6 translation constitute changing the information being transmitted. This analysis fails in two ways. First, refusing to transmit information (e.g., a firewall blocking content deemed to be harmful) is not the same as changing it. Refusing to provide a connection to a user is not the same as changing the information transmitted by the user. Second, the "information" which is changed by such activities as IPV4 - IPV6 translation is not the information sent by the user; it is network management information which is added to the information packets specified by the user, outside the user's control and indeed without the knowledge of most users (since most users are not familiar with the technical details of IP networking). These network management activities are no different from the activities routinely performed by phone networks to route calls--indeed, today the same physical infrastructure is often used to perform both functions, since the phone service backbone and the Internet backbone are in many cases the same networks. Similar remarks apply to services such as filtering by firewalls: phone networks can block calls from certain numbers, for example. Again, the key distinction which the analysis in Paragraph 30 fails to make is between "add-on" services that are for the purpose of facilitating connections, and services that are for the purpose of manipulating the information exchanged by the users at the endpoints. Only the latter are information services; the former are part of the telecommunications service that provides the connection.
In the light of all of the above considerations, the FCC should continue to regulate broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service.

I am a reasonably informed internet consumer and do not support any plan to dismantle net neutrality rules, or the Title II classification for internet service providers. Any suggestions that that the telecommunications industry is competitive, or that the behavior of Comcast, Verizon, AT&T and TWC are characteristic of a competitive market landscape, are simply not credible. 

I can see plainly that the current FCC leadership has made up its mind. I can also see plainly that the plan is to allow ISPs to extract maximum revenue from me, the consumer, with a minimum of actual service provided. This is not a pro-consumer move. To address the claim that this plan will encourage innovation, I have to point out that any company will innovate in something, the question is merely where that innovation provides the largest payoff. In this case, the FCC is moving to encourage innovation in anti-competitive business practices, rent-extraction, and a plethora of questionable advertising and billing policies of which the telecommunications industry has a unique and storied history. 

In conclusion, this whole plan will affect me negatively and I know it.

Net neutrality is necessary for the internet to function in a free and open manner. Allowing ISP's to throttle traffic from certain sites will allow them to charge both for consumer access to the internet and then charging again for the content providers. They want to basically charge twice, when what is being paid for is access to the sites that ISP's would be throttling. By throttling traffic, they allow for circumstances where a certain website will have advantages over other sites. This would fundamentally change the way that the internet works today and would stifle innovation and growth in any tech sectors that make use of the internet. By getting rid of net neutrality rules, you give complete and total control of access to websites to the ISP's themselves. This means that three or four companies would essentially be the gatekeepers of knowledge when it comes to the internet. The potential for censorship and unfair and unethical business practices are outrageous and ridding the internet of net neutrality would be the biggest step that could possibly be taken to cripple the internet and Silicon Valley. Not only is it ethically wrong to allow the ISP's to charge sites various rates, but it is economically unsound to be putting such restrictions on the tech sector. By doing so, millions of dollars will be lost, making it both an ethically and economically unsound idea.

For these reasons I urge you to fully repeal the Obama/Wheeler Internet regulations.

Leave the current provisions, enacted under Tom Wheeler, in place.  Do not strip away consumer protections.  Close regulation of the internet is necessary, as it has become a utility.

The plan to eliminate the previous administration's "Net Neutrality" rules does NOT help consumers. The rollback, AT BEST will put us back to the situation we were in before TItle II was implemented. We gave businesses the chance to to adhere to "rules" and the FCC lost the court case when they tried to hold the business to the the rules.\n\nThe corporations don't need your help. We do. Don't reverse the protections we had to fight for.

The beauty and wonder of the Internet is that a user can go to any website without any hindrance. A request to YouTube is treated to the same was as fcc.gov.

Therefore, all Internet traffic should be treated identical, regardless of whether the end user is using Google or Wikipedia or YouTube in the same way that all electricity traffic should be treated identical regardless of whether the end user is powering a toaster or microwave.

To do anything else will stifle competition because only the the large websites will be able to pay to not have their feed throttled and end users will see no benefit.

I am opposed to the proceeding noted in this comment.

I fully support the implementation of Title II regulations on Internet Service Providers (ISPs) for the purposes of enforcing Net Neutrality rules on providers. I would further request discussion on Local Loop Unbundling (LLU) as a means to foster competition in the market by removing a barrier to entry.

I am against paid prioritization, otherwise known as "fast lanes" that benefit larger entities in the market at the expense of smaller or newer ones. This includes "zero rated" data. All legal data should be treated as equal, possibly with few exceptions for data related to security and medical needs, just to name a few. A large company like Hulu should not be able to pay for better interconnect speeds to customers over a newer entity in the market.

As ISPs have grown in size they have swallowed one another to form larger and larger private entities, while simultaneously avoiding competing with those who remain across many parts of the country. A light touch was beneficial early on, but this was when the Internet was largely new as a consumer level product. Today there's hardly a business or individual citizen who's doesn't rely on the Internet in some form or another. Several markets are changing, and the proposed nixing of Title II and Net Neutrality regulations reeks of little more than greed while clinging to outdated business models from those with the money and power to make it happen. Rather than actually compete and innovate, they would rather force their customers to cling to their old ways for no other reason than, "We own the means of access."

I would implore Mr. Pai and other members of the FCC to strike down this proposal and move forward with implementing Title II regulations on ISPs, along with LLU as a means to foster actual competition in the market. These two matters together,  I feel, will do more to foster competition and innovation in the market.

Regards,

Matthew R. DeGoey

This rule will do nothing but harm small businesses and create a corporate stranglehold on the free flow of information. If you repeal net neutrality you will change the internet for the worst. Please do not do this. You are only handing power to people who are greedy and have no true loyalty to the people of the united states as most of the corporations benefiting from repealing these rules are of multinational interest.

The Constitution empowers the Congress to pass laws establishing post offices and post roads, a necessity given the government must be able to communicate with its citizens to fulfill the various duties the Constitution imposes. But digital communications have become the common means of communication, and the government has a duty to ensure that the internet is fulfilling the requirement as a modern post road.\n\nTo the extent that any change in regulation would erode the capacity or delay the recognition of the network as the post road of the modern day, I believe it is misguided and ignores the direction that society is moving in. The government does not accept the tampering or undermining of the postal system, and it should not tolerate any changes to internet regulation that would pose a threat to its taking up that role over time.

The government, and the associated regulatory agencies of the government, exist to benefit the human citizens (lawful citizens) that they serve. The laws and regulations enacted by the governing bodies of this country should not squelch the voice, welfare, and freedom of those whom they serve. Any proposed regulation, or proposed repeal of current regulations, that would allow soulless, non-citizen corporations to monetarily benefit at the expense of the lawful citizens should not be passed.  Net Neutrality provides the lawful citizens of the United States of America one of the few avenues available to equally express their views and exercise their freedoms.  Ending Net Neutrality would be a regressive move that further divides our country and would be a clear indication that the government, and the regulatory agencies of the government, value non-citizen corporations over the lawful citizens of the United States of America.  Do not blemish the reputation of our country by dividing us through regressive regulation that carves deep chasms between lawful citizens, corporations, and governing bodies.  We are supposed to be One Nation. Maintain Net Neutrality.

Anyone who has a minimal understanding of IP and the internet would see that this filing is designed to reduce performance and increase costs. Since there is no competition for IP services except for the few locations that have Verizon and another carrier the carriers will be able to reduce performance and increase prices at will. Counting IP services provided by cellular phone companies is irrelevant - those services do not compete with wired services using coax or fiber or copper and any assertion to the contrary is specious.

Please do not remove or change the regulations to Eliminate the existing Net Neutrality rules that are in place at this time.  Allowing ISP's to sell my usage or allowing them to throttle sites I go to that they do not get payments from is NOT what a free and open internet is.

It is in the best interest of the American people to allow the internet to continue to be open and unrestricted for everyone. We rely heavily upon the internet for information, education, and business. Doing anything that would allow ISPs or other corporations to restrict access or drive up prices for Internet usage will have a serious detrimental effect on our workforce and economy.\nPlease reconsider doing anything that would change our net neutrality. It will have a serious impact on the way we live our lives.

Support net neutrality!  Private businesses can't be trusted to do what's in the best interest of the wider public.  There's not enough competition between internet providers for them to keep each other in check, so there need to be rules. Strict rules.\n\n(Of course, Ajit Pai is a garden variety corrupt stooge, so I don't think he has the wider public's best interest at heart.  History will judge him and his party harshly.)

The Fact Sheet asserts that "utility-style regulations risks that [internet] innovation, serving ultimately to threaten the open Internet it purported to preserve," yet it does not express how those regulations risk innovation or threaten an open internet. On the contrary, the utility-style regulations that force ISPs to serve all traffic equally safeguards the innovation the FCC claims to value by disallowing ISPs from censoring content through degradation of bandwidth. Open flow of information is vital to innovation. I urge the FCC to reconsider this course of action.
Refer to Attachment(s).

Please DO NOT KILL Net Neutrality. It's the foundation of a free and open internet, and ensures all parties regardless of financial backing or other biases are on EQUAL FOOTING in regards to accessibility and reach on the internet, and it is vital that the new frontiers we are expanding on (the internet) is not tainted by the biases of the past. Economic power-houses should NOT have the ability to throw their weight around to silence smaller critics based solely on the amount of money they can throw at the problem!

Guys, I seriously don't understand your reasoning here. By killing net neutrality, you're basically giving ISPs the right to decide what I can see on the internet. What are we going to do if all of a sudden Comcast or Verizon decides that they want to charge Republican-leaning websites more than liberal ones? Or if, say, Burger King gives them some large amount of money to slow down McDonald's websites? The possibilities for abuse are endless, especially given the pretty fishy business practices most ISPs are known to engage in. 

And I don't at all understand how this is supposed to help the consumer. You've said that maybe they could raise money by charging companies more for better speed, and then they could pass that on to the rest of us via lower prices, but I just don't buy that argument. History pretty clearly shows that big powerful companies will do anything they can to remain big and powerful. I see no reason to think this time will be any different. 

tl;dr - I support net neutrality, and hope that the FCC keeps it around.

The draft seeks comment on the analysis in Paragraph 27. This analysis purports to show that broadband Internet service is an information service because it provides users the "capability for generating, acquiring, storing, transforming, processing, retrieving, utilizing, or making available information via telecommunications." The argument given is that broadband Internet service allows users to do all these things. However, this is not the same as providing the capability to do these things. To see why, consider that providing users Internet services over dialup phone lines also allows users to do all these things; but the phone lines themselves are telecommunications services, not information services. Why? Because providing the user dialup Internet, by itself, does not provide them the capability to do all these things. That capability is provided by the endpoints: the users' computers, and the computers hosting the Internet services that the users connect to.

Exactly the same is true of broadband Internet services provided by ISPs: by themselves, they do not provide users the capability to do all these things. They only provide connections between computers at the endpoints that provide those capabilities. It is the services provided by the Internet hosts that users connect to that are "information services". The broadband Internet services that allow users to connect to those hosts are telecommunications services, and should be regulated as such.

ISPs object to analyses like the one above because they claim that they also provide the actual information services--in other words, they also provide Internet hosts that function as email servers, web servers, etc. But it is obvious that those services are separate from the broadband connection services provided by those same ISPs, because users can make use of the latter without making use of the former at all. I am such a user: I use the broadband Internet connection provided by my ISP, but I do not use any of the information services they provide; I do not use their email, their web hosting, etc. I use other Internet hosts provided by other companies for those services. The fact that ISPs offer information services as well as telecommunications services does not make their telecommunications services into information services; an ISP's choice of business model cannot change the nature of a particular service it provides. Broadband Internet connections are obviously a telecommunications service, and should be regulated as such, regardless of what other services ISPs would like to bundle with them. The FCC should continue to regulate broadband Internet service as a telecommunications service.
